{{Infobox ethnic group | image = File:Tiflis Muslim Women's Benevolent Society.jpg | image_caption = Azerbaijani women of Tiflis, 1910
| group = Azerbaijanis in Georgia | total = 233,024 | total_year = 2014 | total_source = census | total_ref = <ref name="2014 census">[http://pop-stat.mashke.org/georgia-ethnic-loc2014.htm Ethnic Composition of Georgia: 2014 Census].</ref>
| genealogy = | regions = [[Kvemo Kartli]]{{·}}[[Kakheti]]{{·}}[[Shida Kartli]]{{·}}[[Mtskheta-Mtianeti]]
| languages = [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]]{{·}}[[Georgian language|Georgian]] | religions = [[Islam]] | related_groups = [[Azerbaijanis]]: ([[Terekeme people]], [[Karapapak]]) and [[Meskhetian Turks]] | footnotes = }}
'''Azerbaijanis in Georgia''' or '''Georgian Azerbaijanis''' ({{lang-az|Gürcüstan azərbaycanlıları}}, {{lang-ka|აზერბაიჯანელები საქართველოში}}) are [[Azerbaijani people]] in [[Georgia (Country)|Georgia]], and are [[Georgia (Country)|Georgian]] citizens and permanent residents of ethnic Azerbaijani background. According to the 2002 census, there are 284,761 ethnic Azerbaijanis living in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].<ref>[http://www.statistics.ge/main.php?pform=14&plang=1 ''State Statistics Department of Georgia: 2002 census] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060831230321/http://www.statistics.ge/main.php?pform=14&plang=1 |date=August 31, 2006 }}'' (retrieved 16 July 2006)</ref> Azerbaijanis comprise 6.5% of Georgia's population and are the country's largest ethnic minority, inhabiting mostly rural areas like [[Kvemo Kartli]], [[Kakheti]], [[Shida Kartli]] and [[Mtskheta-Mtianeti]], a region broadly referred to as [[Borchali]]. There is also a historical Azerbaijani community in the capital city of [[Tbilisi]] (previously known as Tiflis) and smaller communities in other regions.<ref name="2002 census">{{cite web|title=Ethnic Groups by Major Administrative-territorial Units|url=http://www.geostat.ge/cms/site_images/_files/english/census/2002/03%20Ethnic%20Composition.pdf|publisher=National Statistics Office of Georgia|accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> There were some tensions in the late 1980s in the Azerbaijani-populated regions of Georgia; however, they never escalated to armed clashes.<ref name=cornell>Cornell, Svante E., [http://www.silkroadstudies.org/new/inside/publications/0419dissertation.pdf ''Autonomy and Conflict: Ethnoterritoriality and Separatism in the South Caucasus – Case in Georgia''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630141309/http://www.silkroadstudies.org/new/inside/publications/0419dissertation.pdf |date=2007-06-30 }}. Department of Peace and Conflict Research, Report No. 61. p. 160. University of Uppsala, {{ISBN|91-506-1600-5}}.</ref>
==History== {{Azerbaijanis}} [[Image:Tiflis, Tatar square and bazaar (A).jpg|thumb|200px|left|Azerbaijani quarter of Tbilisi, 1870]] Historically, Azeris in Georgia have succeeded in preserving their ethnic identity and have not been touched by ethnic and/or linguistic assimilation processes observed among many other ethnic communities in the country. Natalia Volkova explained this by the large size of the community and its tendency to being restricted to a specific geographical area. The other reason was that unlike most of their neighbours, Azeris historically adhered to [[Islam]], which weakened possibilities of [[interfaith marriage|intermarriage]] or any other type of close contact with people of other faiths. Finally, the fact that the [[Azerbaijani language|Azeri language]] for a long time enjoyed the status of the language of interethnic communication (see ''Language'') reduced the need of knowing languages of the neighbours, preventing eventual language shift. Volkova noted that as of 1976, cases of assimilation of Azeris even in the smallest communities were unheard of.<ref name="volkova">Natalia Volkova. "Ethnic Processes in the Georgian SSR"; p. 17. In: Gardanov, Valentin (ed.). ''Ethnic and Cultural-Domestic Processes in the Caucasus''. Moscow: Nauka, 1978.</ref>
===Middle Ages=== Georgia's Azerbaijani population traces its roots to the events following the [[Seljuq Empire|Seljuk]] invasion in the second half of the eleventh century, when [[Oghuz Turks|Oghuz]] tribes settled in southern Georgia. To oppose being subjected to the Seljuk Empire, Georgians allied with the [[Cumans]] (a group of [[Kipchak people|Kipchak]] tribes to the north of the [[Caucasus]]) thus allowing for more Turkic migration into the region. In the 1480s, groups of Azeris originally from [[Qazakh]], [[Pambak, Lori|Pambak]] and Shuragel further settled along the banks of the rivers [[Aghstafa River|Aghstafa]] and [[Debed]].<ref name="institute">{{cite web|url=http://www.history.az/pdf.php?item_id=20100816020426434&ext=pdf|title=Кавказский этнографический сборник |publisher=www.history.az|author=Институт этнологии и антропологии им. Н.Н. Миклухо-Маклая}}{{quote|{{lang-ru|Когда же Давид Строитель в начале XII в., усиливая военную мощь Грузии, поселяет в стране 45 тыс. кипчакских семей, то тем самым образуется значительный массивы тюркоязычного населения. Период наступления персидских шахов на Грузию оставляет след поселением в 1480-х гг. азербайджанцев по южным рубежам страны — по р. Акстафе, Дебет и др. (казахская, памбакская и шурагельская группы)...}}}}</ref> Starting in the sixteenth century, [[Qizilbash]] tribes started migrating and settling on both banks of the [[Kura (Caspian Sea)|Kura]] River in Lower Kartli, in the valleys of [[Algeti River|Algeti]] and [[Khrami|Ktsia]], in the Dabnisi Gorge, and in [[Somkhiti]]. By the beginning of the seventeenth century, they spread eastward into fertile lands of Karaiazi (modern-day [[Gardabani Municipality]]) and in the west, they reached [[Shaumiani|Shulaveri]] and the Dmanisi Gorge.<ref name="bregadze">Bregadze, N. A. "K voprosu ob ètničeskom sostave naselenija Gruzii v XVIII v." In: V. K. Gardanov (ed.). ''Kavkazskij ètnografičeskij sbornik'', 6: 238-253; p. 250</ref> Their consolidation led to the formation of the Azeri community.<ref>[http://www.kulichki.com/~gumilev/HE2/he2510.htm The Ancient Orient. Transcaucasia in the 11th–15th centuries] by [[Lev Gumilev]]</ref> The area populated by ethnic Azeris today is historically known as Borchali (which in the form ''Burjoglu'' was originally the name of a Turkic tribe that settled there in the seventeenth century).<ref>[http://grants.rsu.ru/osi/Don_NC/Middle/Polovci.htm Cumans]. The Don and the North Caucasus in the 4th–12th centuries</ref> The area in turn gave its name to the Sultanate of Borchali that existed there from 1604 to 1755 with its capital in [[Aghjakala|Aghjagala]]<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=KcxSAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA151&lpg=PA151 "Aghjagala"]. Encyclopædic Lexicon, 1835.</ref> (a mediaeval fortress whose ruins nowadays lie near Kushchi, [[Marneuli Municipality]]), later turned into a [[mouravi|mouravate]] (district) under the suzerainty of Georgia.<ref>[http://saunje.ge/index.php?id=109&lang=ru «Грузинская советская энциклопедия», ст. «Борчало». Тбилиси, 1965]</ref> Furthermore, up to 15,000 Turkic-speaking families had been resettled in [[Kakheti]] at the beginning of the seventeenth century by [[Abbas I of Persia]] following a series of punitive campaigns he had launched against his Georgian subject, [[Teimuraz I of Kakheti]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gatchina3000.ru/big/049/49932_brockhaus-efron.htm|title=Кахетия |publisher=Брокгауз-Ефрон }}</ref> However, those settlers were almost entirely annihilated less than a decade later in the course of an uprising in Kakheti.<ref name="bregadze"/> The area of Azeri settlement spread northward into the [[Tsalka Plateau]] throughout the eighteenth century<ref>Pankratis Papounidis. [http://papounidis.com/naselenie-punkti/95-tsalka-georgia Tsalka – Brief Historical Facts]. 26 August 2010.</ref> and further westward into Bashkechid (modern [[Dmanisi Municipality]] and its vicinity) by the early nineteenth century.<ref>Н.Г. Волкова Азербайджанцы Грузии (По материалам полевых исследований 1973—1976 гг.) // Полевые исследования Института этнографии, 1976. — М.: Наука, 1978. — С. 110.</ref>
===Imperial Russian rule=== [[Image:1900TBSBazaarRugealer.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Muslim merchants selling rugs in Tiflis, ca. 1900]] After Russia conquered the [[South Caucasus]] and [[Dagestan]] from [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar Iran]] following the [[Russo-Persian War (1804-1813)]], the [[Russo-Persian War (1826-1828)]] and the out-coming treaties of [[Treaty of Gulistan|Gulistan]] and [[Treaty of Turkmenchay|Turkmenchay]],<ref>Allen F. Chew. "An Atlas of Russian History: Eleven Centuries of Changing Borders". Yale University Press, 1967. pp 74.</ref> the government reorganised the Kingdom of Georgia into a [[Georgia Governorate|governorate]], with subdivisions of its own, five of which were referred to as the Tatar ranges (the Czarist nomenclature used the word "Tatar" for Azeri), namely Borchali, Pambak, Shuragel, Kazakh, and Shamshadin.<ref>G. Galoyan. ''Russia and the People of Transcaucasia''. Mysl, 1976; p. 187.</ref> In 1868, the latter two became part of the [[Elisabethpol Governorate]], while the former three were incorporated into the [[Tiflis Governorate]] as the Borchali uyezd. The plains of the uyezd were mainly Azeri-populated: out of 63 villages in the Borchali Plain covering 390 square versts (equal to 444 square kilometres) of land, 61 were populated with Azeris.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=hGQdAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA45 Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopaedia]: "Borchali Plain". V. 7, p. 451.</ref>
In Tiflis, Azeris have historically populated the neighbourhood of Ortachala (from [[Azerbaijani language|Azeri]] ''orta'', meaning "central, middle", and [[Georgian language|Georgian]] ჭალა (''ch'ala''), meaning "green coastal area"), also known as Maidan ({{lang-az|Meydan}}, meaning "square") or Sheitanbazar ({{lang-az|Şeytanbazar}}, meaning "Devil's market"),<ref>[http://diversity.ge/rus/resources.php?coi=0%7C13%7C14%7C12 Azeris]. Diversity.ge.</ref><ref name="divhc">[http://www.diversity.ge/rus/resources.php?coi=0|13|14|12 Diversity.ge - History and Culture - Azeris].</ref> as well as Seidabad ({{lang-az|Seyidabad}}; "city of [[sayyid]]s"), the old baths district.<ref>Alexander Ostrovsky. ''Who Stood Behind Stalin?'' Olma Media Group, 2002; p. 106.</ref>
In November 1905, Tiflis almost became an arena of [[Armenian–Tatar massacres of 1905–1907|Armenian–Azeri ethnic clashes]], which had already affected and caused violent conflicts and massacres in the rest of the South Caucasus. The Armenian population of the city at the time was 50,000, putting the 1,000 Azeris in a dangerous situation. Militia units of the Armenian nationalist [[Dashnaktsutiun]] party seized control of key positions. The Azeris were assisted by 2,000 mounted volunteers from Borchali. By three o'clock in the afternoon on 27 November there were already 22 killed and wounded.<ref>''The Tiflis Leaflet''. 27 November 1905.</ref> In response, social democrat labourer activists organised a peaceful rally, calling on both parties not to engage in a conflict, and managed to acquire arms from the [[Caucasus Viceroyalty (1844-1881)|Viceroyalty of the Caucasus]] in order to patrol the streets. Following mediation, both sides came to a peaceful agreement on 1 December 1905, and the Borchalians left the city.<ref>''Novoe Obozrenie'', 28 November 1905.</ref>
In 1919, during Georgia's [[Democratic Republic of Georgia|brief independence]], 34-year-old Parikhanim Sofiyeva, an Azeri woman from the village of Karajalari near [[Gardabani|Karaiazi]], won the parliament election in her constituency, becoming the first democratically elected Muslim woman in the history of the Caucasus and one of only five Georgian female MPs at the time.<ref>{{ka icon}} [http://archive.ge/ka/blog/9 Matriarch of Karaiazi - Parikhanim Sofiyeva].</ref>
===Soviet rule=== Under [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] rule, Azeris constituted the third largest ethnic minority in the country (after Armenians and Russians), but their numbers grew constantly due to a high [[birth rate]], almost twice as high as for ethnic Georgians as of 1989,<ref name="diversity">Mamuka Komakhia. [http://diversity.ge/rus/resources.php?coi=0%7C13%7C13 Ethnic Minorities in Georgia]. ''Diversity.ge''.</ref> as well as a low rate of immigration. Due to this, the numbers of Azeris rose to make them Georgia's largest minority ethnic group by 2002.
In March 1944, 3,240 ethnic Azeris and [[Kurds in Georgia|Kurds]] living in the capital city of Tbilisi were forcibly relocated to rural parts of Kvemo Kartli, as persons "deliberately avoiding working in the agricultural sector".<ref name="polyan">Pavel Polyan. [http://www.memo.ru/history/deport/polyan2.htm Not Voluntarily: History and Geography of Forced Relocations in the USSR]. Memorial.</ref> Only 31 Azeri families were permitted to stay in Tbilisi, mostly military personnel, handicapped war veterans and university students.<ref name="Скепсис">{{cite news | title=Депортация народов|publisher=Научно-просветительский журнал «Скепсис»| url=http://scepsis.ru/library/id_1237.html|author=Nikolai Bugai}}</ref>
In 1944, in the midst of the [[population transfer in the Soviet Union]], a decree was issued by the [[Moscow]]-seated government, according to which tens of thousands of residents of the southern border regions of Georgia were to be forcibly relocated to [[Central Asia]] for national security reasons. The decree made provision for the relocation of [[Meskhetian Turks]], Kurds, [[Hamshenis|Hamsheni Armenians]] and "others", though the latter category underlyingly referred to Azeris living in [[Samtskhe-Javakheti]] and [[Adjara|Ajara]]. Georgian [[NKVD]] officers made no distinction between the Azeris and the key deportation target groups, as together with Kurds and Hamsheni Armenians, they were seen as "Turkish-oriented".<ref name="zemskov">Viktor Zemskov. ''Special Settlers in the USSR in 1930–1960''. Moscow: Nauka, 2003.</ref> In 1949, it was revealed that out of almost 100,000 deportees, 24,304 were Azeris.<ref name="polyan"/><ref name="zemskov"/>
Azeris living in rural parts of the country were mainly engaged in agriculture and animal husbandry in [[kolkhoz]]es and [[sovkhoz]]es, as well as small-scale trade and industry. Farmer unions were assigned relatively small units of land, which, however, gave more output than most state-owned lands elsewhere in Georgia.<ref name="trier">Tom Trier & Medea Turashvili. [http://ecmicaucasus.org/upload/publications/monograph_6_en.pdf Resettlement of Ecologically Displaced Persons Solution of a Problem or Creation of a New Eco-Migration in Georgia 1981 – 2006]. ECMI Monograph #6. August 2007</ref> Factors such as fertile land, proximity of the capital city and easy access to major Soviet markets allowed Azeri farmers to enjoy relatively prosperous lives, according to Soviet standards.<ref name="cipdd">[http://pdc.ceu.hu/archive/00003218/01/potential_for_conflict.pdf Potential for Conflict Related to Land Problems in Georgia's Marneuli and Gardabani Districts]. Joint report by the German Organization for Technical Cooperation (GTZ) and the Caucasus Institute of Peace, Democracy and Development (Tbilisi), 2006; p. 4</ref> Azeris also occupied many top posts in local governments across Kvemo-Kartli.<ref name="obstacles"/>
===Gamsakhurdia's presidency=== During Georgia's movement toward independence from the Soviet Union, the Azeri population expressed fear for its fate in independent Georgia. In the late 1980s, most ethnic Azeris occupying local government positions in the Azeri-populated areas were removed from their positions.<ref name="borch">{{cite news | script-title=ru:Интеграция национальных меньшинств в регионах Грузии Самцхе-Джавахети и Квемо Картли| author=Jonathan Wheatley|publisher=European Centre for Minorities| url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:BBG74kd64TgJ:www.ecmi.de/download/working_paper_44_rus.pdf+%D0%98%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F+%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D1%85+%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C%D1%88%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2+%D0%B2+%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%85+%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BC%D1%86%D1%85%D0%B5-%D0%94%D0%B6%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%85%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8+%D0%B8+%D0%9A%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%BE+%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%B8+2009&hl=az&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESh1hPuEOMWy5X-oNkYMYIhDbWbp-ul1v5DVkq8nBGH8ovDhqwf-3bMQkemqZgcKN11J_TcCJJUrB68RuI9PCTclFpvZ5kCCQZwfMYbxraS84fIueqRPe09MvCkGpp-UGXqJZB2L&sig=AHIEtbTvCxOo6X9bFRu2KwSdGhMjpacalQ| date=September 2009| language=Russian}}</ref> In 1989, there were changes in the ethnic composition of the local authorities and the resettlement of thousands of eco-migrants who had suffered from landslides in the mountainous region of [[Svaneti]]. The local Azeri population, accepting of the migrants at first, demanded only to resolve the problem of Azeri representation on the municipal level. The demands were ignored; later the eco-migrants, culturally different from the local population and facing social hardships, were accused of attacks and robbery against the Azeris,<ref name="trier"/> which in turn led to demonstrations, ethnic clashes between [[Svans]] and Azeris, demands for an Azeri autonomy in Borchali and for the expulsion of Svan immigrants from Kvemo-Kartli.<ref>{{cite news | title=Ethnic Minorities in Eastern and Southern Georgia | author=Alexander Kukhinadze |publisher=Memorial| url=http://www.memo.ru/hr/referats/selfdet/Chapter16.htm| language=Russian}}</ref><ref name="minorities">{{cite web|url=http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/europe/178_georgia_s_armenian_and_azeri_minorities_rus.ashx |title=Georgia's Armenian and Azeri minorities |publisher=Report 178 Europe |date=22 November 2006 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61CUZJpLe?url=http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/europe/178_georgia_s_armenian_and_azeri_minorities_rus.ashx |archivedate=2011-08-25 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The antagonism reached its peak during the presidency of Zviad Gamsakhurdia (1991–1992), when hundreds of Azeri families were forcibly evicted from their homes in Dmanisi and Bolnisi by [[Mkhedrioni|nationalist paramilitaries]] and fled to Azerbaijan. Thousands of Azeris emigrated in fear of nationalist policies.<ref name="minorities"/> In his speech in [[Kvareli]], Gamsakhurdia accused the Azeri population of Kakheti of "holding up their heads and measuring swords with Kakheti".<ref name="mark">{{ru icon}} [[Sergey Markedonov]] [http://www.ipma.ru/publikazii/etnosotn/1008.php The Land and Will of Zviad Gamsakhurdia] // Institute of Political and Military Analysis. 4 April 2007.</ref> The Georgian nationalist press expressed concern with regard to the fast natural growth of the Azeri population.<ref name="diversity"/>
Although ethnic oppression in the 1990s did not take place on a wide scale, minorities in Georgia, especially Azeris and [[Ossetians]], encountered the problem of dealing with nationalist organisations established in some parts of the country. Previously not prone to migrating, Azeris became the second largest emigrating ethnic community in Georgia in the early 1990s, with three-quarters of these mainly rural emigrants leaving for Azerbaijan and the rest for Russia. Unlike other minority groups, many remaining Azeris cited attachment to their home communities and unwillingness to leave behind well-developed farms as their reason to stay.<ref name="diversity"/> Furthermore, Georgian-born Azeris who immigrated to Azerbaijan at various times, including 50,000 Georgian-born spouses of Azerbaijani citizens, reported bureaucratic problems faced in Azerbaijan, with some unable to acquire Azerbaijani citizenship for nearly 20 years.<ref>Ulviyya Akhundova. [http://www.zerkalo.az/2012-07-04/politics/30286p1-read Serve but Don't Expect Citizenship]. ''Zerkalo''. 4 July 2012.</ref>
===Shevardnadze's presidency=== After the overthrow of Gamsakhurdia, the new president [[Eduard Shevardnadze]] refused to pursue nationalist policies, and his good relationship with his former fellow [[Politburo]] member [[Heydar Aliyev]], then president of Azerbaijan, ensured safety for Georgia's Azeri community.<ref name="diversity"/> However, Jonathan Wheatley characterises Shevardnadze's policy towards Kvemo-Kartli as "benign neglect", pursued through "patron-client linkages" and weak efforts to integrate ethnic minorities with the rest of the country.<ref name="obstacles"/>
In 1995, Shevardnadze appointed Levan Mamaladze governor of the province of Kvemo-Kartli, even though the governor's duties were never clearly outlined in the legislature at the time. Mamaladze reportedly used his power to secure ethnic Azeri votes for Shevardnadze and his political party and tolerated corruption in the region.<ref>{{cite news | title=Defusing Conflict in Tsalka District of Georgia| author=Jonathan Wheatley|publisher=European Centre for Minorities| url=http://www.ecmicaucasus.org/upload/publications/working_paper_36_rus.pdf | date=December 2006| language=Russian}}</ref> According to Jonathan Wheatley, it was on Mamalalze's recommendation that six Azeris became Members of Parliament in the [[Georgian parliamentary election, 1999|1999 election]] and later joined the Alliance for a New Georgia that he had helped form. At the same time, members of the local government were dominated by ethnic Georgians appointed by him, including heads of all majority-Azeri municipalities.<ref name="obstacles">Jonathan Wheatley. ''Obstacles Impeding the Regional Integration of the Kvemo Kartli Region of Georgia''. European Centre for Minority Issues Working Paper #23. February 2005</ref> In a 2003 interview, then Prime Minister and future President [[Mikheil Saakashvili]] criticised Mamaladze for carrying out a smearing campaign against opposition parties and soliciting Azeri votes by spreading rumours that the new government would organise mass deportations of Georgia's Azeri population.<ref>[[Elmar Huseynov]]. [http://www.monitorjournal.com/arxiv/heftelik-39-saak.htm Fox Hunter] (interview with Mikheil Saakashvili. ''Monitor''. 22 November 2003.</ref> Mamaladze left the country soon after Shevardnadze's resignation in November 2003.<ref name="obstacles"/>
===After the Rose Revolution=== Mikheil Saakashvili's government, which came in power after the 2003 [[Rose Revolution]], took steps towards integrating the country's minorities by attempting to enhance the educational system (see ''Education'').<ref name="sjones">Stephen Jones. [https://books.google.com/books?id=xfXbAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA53 War and Revolution in the Caucasus: Georgia Ablaze]. Routledge, 2013; {{ISBN|1317987632}}; pp. 53–55.</ref>
The new government's efforts to build a professional army changed the military conscription practices and instead allowed many young Azeris and Armenians from impoverished regions (at least before the [[Russo-Georgian War]] of 2008) to be offered real employment opportunities by the Georgian army instead of being dragooned into mandatory military service.<ref name="sjones"/>
As part of his anti-corruption reforms, in 2004, Saakashvili cracked down on [[contraband]] markets. This targeted the economic situation of many Azeris from the border regions who made a living through unencumbered trade with Azerbaijan and even led to protests against what was seen as "unfair punishment".<ref name="sjones"/>
In general, the majority-Azeri regions for the most part demonstrated satisfaction with the United National Movement (UNM), showing varying support for this party in the 2004, 2008 and 2012 elections. Stephen Jones explains this by the fact that minority-populated electoral districts in general showed more irregularities which may indicate that the support for the UNM may have actually been lower than reported. Another explanation, may be that, owing to the highly Soviet-like voting culture in this region, the voters did not want to be seen as disloyal or that they had come under the influence of local ethnic elites who have enough power to sway voting practices.<ref name="sjones"/>
==Present-day==
=== Social integration === [[File:Tbilisi Azeri Quarter.JPG|thumb|View on the Azerbaijani quarter, Tbilisi]] Since Georgia regained its independence in 1991, in addition to nationwide problems such as [[unemployment]], many Azerbaijanis along with other minorities have faced [[social disintegration]] and underrepresentation in the country's legislative, executive and judicial powers, mainly due to the language barrier.<ref name="minorities"/> Emigration and the feeling of alienation decreased in comparison with the early 1990s: according to the 2008 UN Association of Georgia report, 98% of Azeris surveyed in Kvemo Kartli considered Georgia their homeland, 96% acknowledged that the problems they face are common to citizens countrywide and around 90% linked their futures with Georgia.<ref name="una"/> The percentage of mixed marriages remains one of the lowest in the country. Christian-Muslim intermarriage is much lower than Christian-Christian intermarriage between different ethnic groups: According to 2011 state statistics, there were only 2,229 families in Georgia where one spouse was Georgian and the other one Azeri (compared with 19,325 Georgian–Russian, 15,013 Georgian–Armenian, and 11,501 Georgian–Ossetian marriages).<ref name="hwlg">Elene Medzmariashvili, Manana Shekiladze, et al. (ed.) ''[http://www.euroclio.eu/new/index.php/general-assembly/doc_download/1390-work-sheets-how-we-lived-together-in-georgia-in-20th-century-russian How We Lived in Georgia in the Twentieth Century]''. 2011. p. 40</ref>
Azerbaijanis are currently represented in the 235-seat [[Parliament of Georgia]] by three members.<ref>[http://www.parliament.ge/index.php?lang_id=ENG&sec_id=2 ''Members of Parliament''] - Parliament of Georgia.</ref> The language barrier remains a major issue in the integration of the community.<ref>[http://iwpr.net/?apc_state=hrufcrs159818&l=en&s=f&o=159819 Georgian Azeris Locked Out By Language] by Zaza Baazov. ''Institute for War and Peace''. 5 September 2002. Retrieved 1 January 2008</ref> The government has launched various programs and projects in order to help Azerbaijanis integrate into the political life of the country.<ref name=icg>[http://www.crisisgroup.org/home/index.cfm?id=4517&l=1 Georgia’s Armenian and Azeri Minorities], 22 November 2006 ''(free registration needed to view the full report)''</ref>
===1992 land reform=== After the fall of the Communist regime, large areas of state-owned lands could not be maintained by the Georgian government any longer, and a need for their privatisation arose. Champions of the privatisation law believed that private farming would keep the agriculture developing further. However nationalists argued that privatisation of lands populated by ethnic minorities who lived in border regions may lead to [[irredentism|irredentist sentiment]]. In 1992, privatisation law was passed on certain conditions with regard to the border regions, such as the ban on owning land within 21 kilometres from the state border. Large areas of arable land in Gardabani and Marneuli were thus transferred to the control of the [[Ministry of Defense (Georgia)|Ministry of Defence]], and many families ended up owning only 1 to 1.5 hectares of land or less. Although after Mikheil Saakashvili's rise to power in 2004 the ban was lifted, local Azeris complained of unawareness of the changing laws as the main reason for dissatisfaction and expressed scepticism with regard to the situation improving.<ref>Potential for Conflict Related to Land Problems in Georgia’s Marneuli and Gardabani Districts, German Organization for Technical Cooperation, Caucasus Institute for Peace, Democracy and Development, Tbilisi-Marneuli-Gardabani, 2006, pp. 17-18.</ref> As a result, landowners from other parts of the country came to own and rent much of the land (70% according to Azeri non-governmental organisations)<ref>T. Baliyev, L. Tarverdiyev. [http://www.echo-az.com/archive/2004_05/833/politica07.shtml Azeris in Georgia Allowed to Privatise Land]. ''Echo''. May 2004. Retrieved 6 July 2012.</ref> that had been formerly in the possession of the Azeri-populated villages and farmer unions. Other problems include corruption of agrarian establishments, land division and distribution, and priority unduly given to large companies, potential voters and ethnic Georgians.<ref name="cipdd"/> In March 2006, there was an Azeri demonstration held in Marneuli against unfair land privatisation, and several participants were detained.<ref>ECMI, Implementing the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities in Georgia: A feasibility Study, Jonathan Wheatley, ECMI Working Paper 28, October 2006.</ref>
===Renaming of placenames=== [[File:Bolnisi scenery.jpg|thumb|right|250px|View on the Azeri-populated village of Dzveli-Kveshi (Zol-Goyach) near Bolnisi]] The Georgianisation of Georgia's toponymy has been a steady process since the 1930s. It affected placenames of Azeri origin, such as the renaming of Barmaksiz ({{lang-az|Barmaqsız}}) to [[Tsalka]] in 1932,<ref>[http://www.terra.su/full/056.html The Great Encyclopædia]. "Tsalka". Terra Publ.</ref> Aghbulagh ({{lang-az|Ağbulaq}}) to [[Tetritsqaro]] in 1940<ref>R. Kverenchkhiladze. Georgian Soviet Encyclopædia. V. 4, p. 580, Tbilisi, 1979</ref> (by direct translation), Bashkicheti ({{lang-az|Başkeçid}}) to [[Dmanisi]],<ref>V. Jaoshvili, P. Zakaraia, V. Japaridze, G. Lomtatidze. Georgian Soviet Encyclopædia. V. 3, p. 593, Tbilisi, 1978</ref> Karaiazi ({{lang-az|Qarayazı}}) to [[Gardabani]],<ref>V. Jaoshvili. Georgian Soviet Encyclopædia. V. 2, p. 694, Tbilisi, 1977</ref> and Sarvan ({{lang-az|Sarvan}}) to Marneuli<ref>V. Jaoshvili, T. Tordia. Georgian Soviet Encyclopædia. V. 6, p. 488, Tbilisi, 1983</ref> all in 1947. According to the locals, in the 1960s residents of three villages near Gardabani petitioned to Moscow against the plan of renaming their villages, and the names were kept.<ref name="georgiatimes">Kama Rzayeva. [http://www.georgiatimes.info/articles/73268.html Azerbaijan Retracting Its Words?]. Georgia Times. 16 March 2012. Retrieved 5 July 2012.</ref>
During Gamsakhurdia's presidency in the early 1990s, the Azeri-sounding names of 32 villages were changed overnight to Georgian ones by a special decree.<ref name="minorities"/> Their Azeri population has expressed dissatisfaction with this decision<ref name="georgiatimes"/><ref>[http://www.kavkaz-uzel.ru/articles/201322/ Protest in front of Georgian Embassy in Baku]. ''Caucasian Knot''. 17 February 2012. Retrieved 5 July 2012.</ref> and addressed their concerns in writing to president Mikheil Saakashvili, but the problem has not been resolved.<ref>[http://www.faxrali.com/haqqinda.htm Village of Fakhrali: Unofficial Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623231435/http://www.faxrali.com/haqqinda.htm |date=2012-06-23 }}.</ref> In 2009, the Advisory Committee on the [[Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities]] qualified the renaming of Azeri-populated villages as violation of principles of Article 11 of the Framework Convention, to which Georgia is a signatory, and urged the government of Georgia to co-operate with the local ethnic minority to reintroduce the traditional names.<ref name="acfcpnm">[http://www.coe.int/t/dghl/monitoring/minorities/3_fcnmdocs/PDF_1st_OP_Georgia_en.pdf Georgia]. Advisory Committee on the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities. 19 March 2009.</ref>
According to the Human Rights Monitoring Group of Ethnic Minorities, on the updated list of placenames of the [[Ministry of Justice (Georgia)|Ministry of Justice]] Public Registry, Azeri-sounding names of 30 more villages (18 in Marneuli and 12 in Tsalka) were changed to Georgian-sounding ones in 2010–2011.<ref>[http://www.ia-centr.ru/expert/10222/ How Georgian Government "Thanked" Azeris for Support]. IA Centre. 10 April 2011. Retrieved 19 August 2013.</ref>
===Political and social activity=== Of the four ethnic Azeris elected in the Georgian National Assembly in the [[Georgian parliamentary election, 2016|2016 parliamentary election]], three represent the ruling [[Georgian Dream]] (Mahir Darziyev, Ruslan Hajiyev, Savalan Mirzayev) and one the previously-ruling [[United National Movement (Georgia)|United National Movement]] (Azer Suleymanov).<ref>[http://www.parliament.ge/en/parlamentarebi/deputatebis-sia List of MPs – Parliament of Georgia]. Retrieved 28 January 2017.</ref> There are currently three officially registered large Azeri social organisations,<ref>[http://www.diversity.ge/rus/resources.php?coi=0|12|12 Diversity.ge - Ethnic Organisations].</ref> focusing on language instruction, civic education and intercultural communication. However, according to a report by the UN Association of Georgia, Azeri politicians who make it to the national scene often come from Tbilisi and thus maintain weak links with the rural portion of the minority they are supposed to represent.<ref name="una">[http://www.una.ge/pdfs/publications/survey_report_eng.pdf National Integration and Tolerance in Georgia]. Assessment Survey Report 2007-2008.</ref>
===Georgia–Armenia border incidents=== The Advisory Committee on the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities received reports that ethnic Azeris living close to the [[Armenia]]n border often become victims of acts of violence, land and other property seizures and thefts of cattle. Local law enforcement agencies fail to respond adequately to these cases.<ref name="acfcpnm"/> In 2013, members of Azeri NGOs representing seven villages along the Georgia–Armenia border blamed these incidents on Armenian border guards who, according to them, have advanced 100–150 metres into the Georgian territory and are now in control of a local water reservoir that has been used by farmers for irrigation since 1948. They reportedly harass Azeris who try to use the reservoir or herd sheep in the nearby area.<ref>[http://ru.apa.az/news/252261 Принято заявление в знак протеста против захвата армянскими пограничниками земель азербайджанцев в Грузии]. APA. 27 July 2013.</ref>
==Culture== [[File:Borchali rug.png|thumb|right|160px|Nineteenth-century Azeri carpet of the Borchali type]] The art of [[ashik]]s (travelling bards) from the Borchali area has been referred to as the strongest and best-developed Azeri ashik school by Azerbaijani music folklorist Latif Hasanov.<ref>{{az icon}} Latif Hasanov. [http://www.anl.az/down/meqale/tezadlar/2010/dekabr/145875.htm Musical Performance in the Goycha Music Art]. ''Tezadlar''. 16 December 2010. Retrieved 5 January 2015.</ref>
Azeri-populated areas of Georgia, mainly the districts of Marneuli, Bolnisi, Gardabani and Sagarejo, are famous for the production of [[Azerbaijani rug]]s of the Gazakh school of carpet-weaving, which also encompasses western Azerbaijan and northern Armenia. The rugs of this school are all wool, coarsely knotted in the symmetrical knot with a long, lustrous pile, and use strong red, blue, and ivory in bold combinations with relatively simple but dramatic designs.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/313772/Kazakh-rug Britannica Encyclopedia. Kazakh-rugs.] <blockquote>Kazakh rug — floor covering woven by villagers living in western Azerbaijan and in a number of towns and villages in northern Armenia and the adjacent southern part of Georgia. The weavers are probably mostly Azerbaijanian Turks, although it is clear that both Armenians and Georgians have taken part in the production of these rugs. Kazakh rugs are all wool, coarsely knotted in the symmetrical knot with a long, lustrous pile, and use strong red, blue, and ivory in bold combinations with relatively simple but dramatic designs. The rugs seldom exceed about 1,7 × 2 metres (5.5 × 7 feet), and many of the smaller pieces are in prayer rug designs. Many show three medallions of approximately equal size, while another common format involves a central square enclosing geometric figures with two smaller squares at each end.</blockquote></ref>
The city of Tbilisi, or Tiflis, is known as one of the important centres for Azerbaijanis' cultural development. [[Molla Vali Vidadi]], an Azerbaijani poet from the eighteenth century, was at one point known as King [[Erekle II]]'s court poet.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://www.oval.ru/enc/13380.html Molla Vali Vidadi]. ''Great Soviet Encyclopædia''</ref> [[Mirza Fatali Akhundov]], the Azerbaijani enlightened reformist, novelist and dramatist, the pioneer of the theatrical performance in the East, lived and contributed to literature in Tiflis in the mid-nineteenth century, along with his [[Ganja, Azerbaijan|Ganja]]-native teacher [[Mirza Shafi Vazeh]].<ref>[http://literature.aznet.org/literature/vazeh/vazeh_en.htm Mirza-Shafi Vazeh (1794-1852)]. ''Literature.aznet.org''</ref> Both died and were buried in Tiflis. [[File:Azeri drama theatre in Tbilisi.jpg|thumb|left|160px|Tbilisi Azerbaijani Drama Theatre]] The first printed periodical in history to include articles in Azeri, ''Tatarskie vedomosti'', was published in Tiflis in 1832.<ref>[http://enc-dic.com/enc_sie/Azerbadzhanskaja-sovetskaja-socialisticheskaja-respublika-1493.html Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic]. The Great Soviet Encylopædia.</ref> The famous Azerbaijani satirical magazine ''[[Molla Nasraddin (magazine)|Molla Nasraddin]]'' edited by [[Jalil Mammadguluzadeh]] was published in Tiflis in 1906–1917, as were Azerbaijani newspapers from earlier periods (such as ''Ziya'', ''Keshkul'' and ''Sharg-i rus'' in the nineteenth and early twentieth century).<ref>[http://www.azmaison.fr/az/index_az.shtml?id=240;c=2 Mass-Media]. ''Azmaison.fr''</ref> The [[Transcaucasian Teachers Seminary]] which trained professional teachers for secular primary Azerbaijani schools was located in [[Gori, Georgia|Gori]]. Folk singer [[Bulbuljan]], among others, spent 30 years of his life living and performing in Tiflis. Tiflis was also the hometown and academic locale for some of the most prominent Azerbaijani singers, such as [[Rashid Behbudov]] and the first Azerbaijani female opera singer [[Shovkat Mammadova]], as well as to the first professional Azerbaijani female painter [[Geysar Kashiyeva]], and the first female pianist [[Khadija Gayibova]].
Plays by Azeri writers were staged in Tbilisi already in 1872.<ref name="hwlg"/> Today Azeri-language plays are staged at the Tbilisi State Azeri Drama Theatre, established in 1922.<ref>Ilham Rahimli. ''Azeri Theatre of Tiflis''. Baku, 2006</ref> In addition, the Azeri Cultural Centre in Tbilisi, located in the former house of Mirza Fatali Akhundov, is one of several such centres in the country and consists of a museum, a library, a cafe, an art gallery and a wine cellar.<ref>[http://www.1news.az/bomond/cult/20141009021649310.html Museum of Azeri Culture Receives 2014 Architecture Award]. ''1news.az''. 9 October 2014. Retrieved 25 January 2015.</ref> The Azeri Cultural Centre in Marneuli works closely with the [[Heydar Aliyev Foundation]] and the [[State Committee on Work with Diaspora (Azerbaijan)|State Committee on Work with Diaspora of Azerbaijan]], issues the magazines ''Garapapagh'' and ''Meydan'' and manages its own folk dance ensemble ''Sarvan''.<ref>[http://www.diversity.ge/rus/resources.php?coi=0|13|17|12 Azeri Cultural Centre in Marneuli]. Diversity.ge.</ref> There are 15 public libraries with materials available mainly in the Azeri language across the country.<ref>[http://www.diversity.ge/rus/resources.php?coi=0|11|11 Diversity.ge - Culture].</ref> There also exists an Azeri cultural centre in Bolnisi.<ref>[http://www.vesti.az/news/238665#ad-image-10 Brother Georgian Nation to Join Justice for Khojaly Campaign]. ''Vesti.az''. 25 February 2015.</ref> Three Georgian state newspapers, one in Tbilisi and two in Marneuli, are printed in Azeri,<ref>[http://www.diversity.ge/rus/resources.php?coi=0|13|12|13 Diversity.ge - Ethnic Periodicals].</ref> and a newspaper printed in Bolnisi contains a section in Azeri.<ref>[http://www.eaptc.eu/en/program/view-armenia-georgia.html EaPTC Cooperation Programmes: Armenia – Georgia]</ref> Five-minute<ref name="una"/> newscasts in Azeri are aired on Georgia's Public Radio on weekdays.<ref>[http://www.diversity.ge/rus/resources.php?coi=0|13|12|12 Diversity.ge - Radio in Minority Languages].</ref> In March 2015, a new radio station, AGFM, was launched to broadcast in Azeri on a 24-hour basis. It covers the regions of Tbilisi, Rustavi, Gardabani, Marneuli, Bolnisi, Dmanisi, and Tetritsqaro.<ref>[http://vesti.az/news/241033 Azeri-Language Radio Began Broadcast in Georgia]. ''Vesti.az''. 16 March 2015.</ref> Television programs in the Azeri language are broadcast by some regional channels.<ref>[http://realcaucasus.org/217 Azeris of Georgia to Watch News in Their First Language]. ''Real Caucasus''. 14 January 2010. Retrieved 5 July 2012.</ref>
Beginning in 2009, Azeris of Dmanisi have annually held Elat, a summer celebration that historically marked the seasonal migration of Borchali pastoralists from plains into the mountains. The event is attended by tourists from other Azeri-populated parts of Georgia.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://newsgeorgia.ru/society/20140805/216850258.html Azeris of Georgia Marked Elat]. ''News Georgia''. 5 August 2014. Retrieved 5 January 2015.</ref>
On 21 March 2010, Mikheil Saakashvili declared [[Nowruz]], an ancient Near Eastern spring fest celebrated by Azeris, a national holiday in Georgia.<ref>[http://www.kavkaz-uzel.ru/articles/166836/ Nowruz Declared National Holiday in Georgia]. Caucasian Knot. 21 March 2010. Retrieved 21 August 2013.</ref>
==Language== Most Azeris in Georgia speak [[Azerbaijani language|Azeri]] as a first language. Azeris of Tbilisi are mainly bilingual or trilingual, speaking [[Georgian language|Georgian]] and [[Russian language|Russian]] in addition to their native language. On the other hand, Azeris living in almost [[Monoethnicity|monoethnic]] villages in Kvemo Kartli, who constitute the core of Georgia's Azeri population, largely speak little to no Georgian.<ref name="una"/><ref name="gogitidze">[http://bona-mente.az/rus/index.php?newsid=171 Nikoloz Gogitidze: We Are All from the Caucasus].</ref> To Azeris in Georgia, secondary education is available in their native language, which is a remnant Soviet policy.<ref name="una"/> As of 2015, Azeri serves as the language of instruction in 120 schools<ref>[http://new.smr.gov.ge/Uploads/1_e7beda71.pdf Second Opinion on Georgia]. Advisory Committee on the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities. Adopted on 17 June 2015.</ref> in Tbilisi, Kvemo Kartli and Kakheti, a number which went down from 183 as of 1989.<ref>Rashad Rustamov. [http://www.trend.az/news/society/1762661.html#popupInfo Education Ministers of Azerbaijan and Georgia to Discuss Decrease of Azeri Teachers in Georgian Schools]. ''1news.az''. 7 October 2010.</ref> Young Azeris in Georgia who choose to continue their education often apply to universities in Azerbaijan and thus limit their career prospects in their home country.<ref name="gogitidze"/> According to the 2014 census, only 43,579 (18.7%) out of 231,436 Azeris in Georgia reported being able to speak Georgian fluently,<ref name="census2014">[http://census.ge/en/results/census1/demo 2014 Georgian General Population Census - Demographic And Social Characteristics]. Retrieved 21 May 2017.</ref> which is nevertheless more than the 1970 (6%)<ref>Volkova, p. 42.</ref> and the 2002 (15%)<ref name="geostat">[http://geostat.ge/cms/site_images/_files/georgian/census/2002/I%20tomi%20-%20saqarTvelos%20mosaxleobis%202002%20wlis%20pirveli%20erovnuli%20sayovelTao%20aRweris%20Sedegebi.pdf 2002 Census in Georgia: Population by Native Language].</ref> figure. As of 2002, Russian was the most popular second language for Azeris, with 75,207 speakers (26%; up from 17% in 1970).<ref>Volkova, p. 46.</ref> At the same time, 934 Azeris indicated Georgian and 385 indicated Russian as their first language.<ref name="geostat"/>
Up until the early twentieth century, Azeri was the [[lingua franca|language of interethnic communication]] across most of the South Caucasus and the surrounding regions, including much of Georgia, with the exception of the Black Sea coastal regions.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gxXtKAAACAAJ&dq=Nasledie+Chingiskhana Nasledie Chingiskhana] by [[Nikolai Trubetzkoy]]. Agraf, 1999; p. 478</ref> This mainly had to do with the economic practices of the neighbouring (mainly male) population, such as seasonal work, distant pastoralism and trade. Up until the 1930s, large groups of ethnic [[Georgians|Georgian]], [[Armenians|Armenian]], [[Ossetians|Ossetian]] and [[Greeks|Greek]] male population of Tetritsqaro would regularly visit the mainly-Azeri populated region of Marneuli for seasonal work as railway workers, miners, guards and shepherds and used Azeri to communicate with the local population. In the nineteenth century, Georgians of [[Kakheti]] and [[Tusheti]], as well as [[Kist people|Kists]] from the [[Pankisi Gorge]] would herd their sheep down to the pastures in the Azeri-populated lowlands, where they would spend the winter, which also contributed to their knowledge of Azeri. Some Tush Georgians would give their children up for [[fosterage]] (a common practice among peoples of the Caucasus aimed at strengthening intercommunal relations) to Azeri families for the duration of their stay on the winter pastures.<ref>Volkova, p. 51.</ref> In addition, tinsmiths and, less often, shepherds from [[Daghestan]] who visited Georgia around the same time would also use Azeri to communicate with the local population.<ref>Volkova, p. 41.</ref>
Later, due to changing linguistic policies, universal schooling and abandonment of older practices, Azeri significantly lost positions to Georgian and Russian. Volkova noted that as of 1976, Azeri was still used as the language of trade between representatives of different ethnic groups in Tetritsqaro, Dmanisi and Marneuli.<ref>Volkova, p. 45.</ref> In 2002, 218 non-Azeris in Georgia indicated Azeri as their first language and 6,704 more claimed speaking it as a second language.<ref name="geostat"/> The Soviet census recorded [[Turkish language|Turkish-speaking]] [[Urums|Urum Greeks]] of central Georgia as speaking Azeri as a first language, in part due to the fact that their original dialect underwent influence from Azeri over the centuries and shifted towards the latter.<ref>[http://www.geogen.ge/indexen.php?lang=en&id_menu=22&id_menu_up=4&abc=0&fr=&srch= Azerbaijanis in Georgia]. Retrieved 2 October 2006</ref>
==Education== The first European-style school in Georgia with Azeri as the language of instruction opened in Tiflis in 1847, followed by the [[Kizilajlo]] school in 1877. Before the establishment of Soviet power in 1921 and the introduction of compulsory universal education, there had already been 24 such schools across the country.<ref>Gulnara Gocaeva-Memmedova. [http://www.dergikaradeniz.com/web/upload/icerik/28/2.pdf Azerbaijani Schools in Today's Georgia]. ''Karadeniz'', 2015 (28): 29–38.</ref>
There was not much incentive for Azeris to learn Georgian in the Soviet times. Those who chose to pursue post-secondary education in Georgia did so in universities with Russian as the language of instruction, where Georgian was not even offered as a second-language course.<ref name="georgiatimes"/> Since the fall of the Soviet Union, lack of knowledge of the [[official language]] makes it harder for Azeris and other ethnic minorities to be active in many social areas.<ref>[http://www.memo.ru/hr/referats/selfdet/Chapter16.htm ''Ethnic Minorities of Eastern and Southern Georgia''] by Alexander Kukhianidze (in Russian)</ref> Such isolation is furthered by the fact that many rural Azerbaijanis prefer to read newspapers published in Azerbaijani and set up satellite dishes in order to be able to watch channels of neighbouring Azerbaijan, or establish their own community television channels (such as Ellada TV, which functioned in [[Gardabani]] in 1995–1999).<ref>[http://www.media.ge/researches/otsenka_vozmojnostei_kvemo_kartli.pdf Estimating Potential of Kvemo Kartli] (in Russian)</ref>
Teachers and principals of schools where Azeri is the language of instruction report problems with the quality of the printed materials,<ref name="georgiatimes"/> their deficit<ref>Elnur Abdulrahimov. [http://anspress.com/index.php?a=2&lng=ru&nid=125545 Azeri Secondary School Facing Problem]. ANS Press. 11 November 2011. Retrieved 5 July 2012.</ref> and the physical condition of rural Azeri-language schools.<ref>[http://www.epress.am/ru/2012/05/04/%D0%94%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80-%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%B4%D0%B6%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9-%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8B-%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%81.html Azeri School Principal Concerned about Armenian Pupils]. ''Espress.am''. 5 April 2012. Retrieved 5 July 2012.</ref>
The Saakishvili government's educational policy attempted to provide students in majority-Armenian and Azeri areas with improved learning materials and teachers willing to instruct non-native speakers of Georgian. As of 2013, however, the program did not prove very efficient. The standards of the general ability exams considered mandatory and non-mandatory were altered in order to accommodate non-Georgians (for example, the exam on [[Literature of Georgia (country)|Georgian literature]] became optional) and a program funding minority group students wanting to study in the [[United States]] was introduced. On the other hand, the Law on Civil Service (adopted in 1998, but previously applied selectively) which stipulates that all work be carried out in Georgian, was enforced and, in effect, barred many Armenians and Azeris who had been schooled in their native languages not only from working in the civil service, but even accessing it due to insufficient knowledge of Georgian.<ref name="sjones"/>
==Religion== [[File:Tiflis Premazzi.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Shah Ismayil Mosque (left) in [[Luigi Premazzi]]'s painting of old Tbilisi]] Azeris in Georgia are mainly Muslim, with 80% being [[Shiite]] and 20% [[Sunni]],<ref name="divhc"/> a distinction that is not felt much due to religion not occupying an important part of their everyday lives.<ref name="obstacles"/> Georgia's constitution provides for [[religious freedom]], and Azeris have the opportunity to attend mosques in the country. The largest Shiite mosque in Tbilisi was built in 1524 by [[Ismail I]] of Persia.<ref>{{ka icon}} ''Ancient Towns of Georgia: Tbilisi'' (2nd ed.). Tbilisi, 2006. {{ISBN|99940-0-923-0}}</ref> In 1951, during the construction of the [[Metekhi]] bridge the communist government ordered the mosque to be demolished.<ref name="zp">Zaza Piralishvili. [http://www.ca-c.org/annual/2007/19.shtml Conflicts in the Caucasus - International Conference]. 'Religion'. October 2012.</ref> The Sunni mosque was built between 1723 and 1735 by the Ottomans, but it was destroyed in 1740 by reinvanding Persians. In 1864, it was restored and headed by the Teregulovs, a family of [[Volga Tatar]] origin who had settled in Tbilisi two decades prior to that.<ref>[http://uzeyirbook.musigi-dunya.az/RU/data.pl?id=610&lang=RU Teregulovs]. Uzeyir Hajibeyov Encyclopædia.</ref> Since the demolition of the Shiite mosque in 1951, the Shiite Azeris of Tbilisi have attended the Sunni mosque (the only Muslim temple in modern Tbilisi), where the Sunni and Shiite sections were separated by a black curtain. In 1996, the new imam ordered to remove the curtain and both denominations have prayed together ever since.<ref name="zp"/>
Although able to preserve their linguistic and religious identity, the Azeris in Georgia have undergone some influences from Georgian culture, such as mourning over the body of the deceased for three days, while Azeris elsewhere, as most Muslims, generally bury their dead on the day of death before sunset.<ref name="divhc"/>
==Demographics== In 2014, Azeris constituted a majority or a significant (over 10%) minority in the towns and villages across the following municipalities: 58 in Marneuli, 43 in Dmanisi, 37 in Bolnisi, 17 in Gardabani, 11 in Sagarejo, 9 in Lagodekhi, 8 in Kaspi, 8 in Tsalka, 7 in Tetritsqaro, 4 in Mtskheta, 3 in Gori, 2 in Dedoplistsqaro, 1 in Akhmeta, 1 in Kareli, and 1 in Telavi.<ref name="2014 census"/> Ethnic Azeri villages are also among the largest in the country in terms of population.<ref name="obstacles"/>

{{Infobox language family |name=Bahnaric |region=[[Indochina]] |familycolor=Austro-Asiatic |glotto=bahn1264 |glottorefname=Bahnaric |child1=Central Bahnaric |child2=North Bahnaric |child3=West Bahnaric }}
The '''Bahnaric languages''' are a group of about thirty [[Austroasiatic languages]] spoken by about 700,000 people in [[Vietnam]], [[Cambodia]], and [[Laos]]. [[Paul Sidwell]] notes that Austroasiatic/[[Mon–Khmer languages]] are lexically more similar to Bahnaric and [[Katuic languages]] the closer they are geographically, independently of which branch of the family they belong to, but that Bahnaric and Katuic do not have any [[shared innovation]]s that would suggest that together they form a branch of the Austroasiatic family, rather forming separate branches.
==Languages== Internal diversity suggests that the family broke up about 3,000 years ago.{{citation needed|date=June 2009}} North Bahnaric is characterized by a [[register (phonology)|register]] contrast between breathy and modal voice, which in Sedang has tensed to become modal–creaky voice.
[[Lamam language|Lamam]] is a clan name of the neighboring Tampuon and Kaco’.
Sidwell (2009) tentatively classifies the Bahnaric languages into four branches, with [[Cua language (Mon–Khmer)|Cua]] (Kor) classified independently as East Bahnaric.<ref>Sidwell, Paul. 2009. "[https://openresearch-repository.anu.edu.au/handle/1885/49761 How many branches in a tree? Cua and East (North) Bahnaric]". In Evans, Bethwyn (ed). ''Discovering History Through Language: Papers in Honour of Malcolm Ross''. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics.</ref><ref>Sidwell, Paul. 2010. "[http://www.mksjournal.org/mksj39.pdf Cua (Kor) historical phonology and classification]." ''Mon-Khmer Studies'' 39:105-122.</ref>
Unclassified Bahnaric languages of Cambodia include [[Mel language|Mel]], [[Khaonh language|Khaonh]], [[Ra’ong language|Ra’ong]], and [[Thmon language|Thmon]].<ref name="BarrPawley">Barr, Julie and Eric Pawley. 2013. ''[http://www.sil.org/resources/publications/entry/52517 Bahnaric Language Cluster survey of Mondul Kiri and Kratie Provinces, Cambodia]''. SIL International.</ref>

===North Bahnaric=== North Bahnaric consists of a [[dialect chain]] spoken to the north of the [[Chamic languages]].<ref>Sidwell, Edmondson, & Gregerson. 2011. "The North Bahnaric Clade: A Computational Approach." In Srichampa, Sidwell & Gregerson (eds.) ''[http://icaal.org/ICAAL-4.2.pdf Austroasiatic Studies: papers from the ICAAL4: Mon-Khmer Studies Journal Special Issue No. 3]'', pp.23-37</ref> Sedang and Hre have the most speakers, each with about 100,000.
{{clade |label1=North |1={{clade |1=[[Jeh language|Jeh]] |2=[[Halang language|Halang]] |3={{clade |1=[[Kayong language|Kayong]] |2={{clade |1=[[Romam language|Romam]]–[[Kaco' language|Kaco’]] |2={{clade |1=[[Takua language|Takua]] |2={{clade |1=[[Monom language|Monom]] (Bonam, Monam) |2={{clade |1=[[Todrah language|Todrah]] (Didrah, Modrah) |2={{clade |1=[[Sedang language|Sedang]] |2=[[Rengao language|Rengao]] |3=[[Hrê language|Hrê]] }} }} }} }} }} }} }} }}
Other Northern Bahnaric languages, too poorly known to classify further, are [[Duan language|Duan]] and [[Katua language|Katua]].<!--katua is not close to Cua. that's only from contact.-->
===West Bahnaric=== West Bahnaric is a dialect chain to the west of North Bahnaric,<ref name=draft>{{cite web|url=http://email.eva.mpg.de/~wichmann/Sidwell_ASJP_draft.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611042638/http://email.eva.mpg.de/~wichmann/Sidwell_ASJP_draft.pdf |archivedate=2011-06-11 }}</ref> Unlike the other Bahnaric languages to the east, the West Bahnaric languages were under Khmer rather than Chamic influence, and also by the Katuic languages as part of a Katuic-West Bahnaric sprachbund (Sidwell 2003). *West Bahnaric **Brao–Kavet: [[Lave language|Lave]] (Brao), [[Kru'ng language|Kru'ng]], [[Kravet language|Kravet]] **[[Laven language|Laven]], [[Sou language|Sou]] [split?] **[[Nyaheun language|Nyaheun]] **Oi–The: [[Jeng language|Jeng]]; [[Oy language|Oy]], [[Sok language|Sok]], [[Sapuan language|Sapuan]], [[The language|The]]
Sidwell (2003) proposes the following West Bahnaric groupings, with Lavi branching off first, Jru'/Laven, Su', and Juk as forming a branch that had branched off secondarily, and the rest within a core group. [[Jru' language|Jru']] and [[Brao language|Brao]] each have tens of thousands of speakers, while the other languages have no more than 1,000 speakers each.
*West Bahnaric **[[Lavi language|Lavi]] **(branch) ***[[Jru' language|Jru']]/[[Laven language|Laven]], [[Su' language|Su']], [[Juk language|Juk]] ***(branch) ****[[Nyaheun language|Nyaheun]] ****[[Sapuan language|Sapuan]] ****[[Oi language|Oi]]/Sok/[[Cheng language|Cheng]] ****Laveh/[[Brao language|Brao]]
===Central Bahnaric=== Central Bahnaric is a language family divided by the Chamic languages,<ref name=draft/><ref name="autogenerated1">[http://www.anu.edu.au/~u9907217/languages/Bahnaric-Central.html]</ref> Bahnar, Mnong, and Sre (Koho) each have over 100,000 speakers. *Central Bahnaric **[[Alak language|Alak]] **[[Cua language (Mon–Khmer)|Cua]] **[[Taliang language|Taliang]] ([[Kassang language|Kassang]]) **Central South: to the southwest of Chamic: ***[[Tampuon language|Tampuon]] ***[[Bahnar language|Bahnar]] ***South Bahnaric ****Stieng–Chrau: [[Chrau language|Chrau]],<ref name="autogenerated1"/> [[Stieng language|Stieng]] (Bulo, Budeh) ****Sre–Mnong: [[Koho language|Koho]], [[Mnong language|Mnong]]
Kassang is a Bahnaric language (Sidwell 2003), though ''Ethnologue'' lists it as [[Katuic]].
Sidwell (2002, quoted in Sidwell 2003) gives the following classification for the Central Bahnaric languages.<ref>Sidwell, Paul (2002). {{distinguish|chairwoman}} {{refimprove|date=December 2013}} [[File:A charwoman who cleans buses sweeping the floor of a bus 8d32921v.jpg|thumb|A 1943 photograph of a charwoman in [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania, United States]]
A '''charwoman''', '''charlady''', '''chargirl''' or just '''char''' is a cleaning girl or woman who can be employed in houses, shops and/or office buildings. The term charwoman was also used as an official job title in the [[United States]] before 1960, which included use by municipal and state governments and by federal agencies such as the [[Department of Commerce and Labor|U.S. Department of Commerce and Labor]] (such as in the [[Bureau of the Census]] and the [[U.S. Immigration Service|Bureau of Immigration]]). Charwomen were often commonly referred to as scrubwomen. The word has the same root as "chore woman", one hired to do odd chores around the house.
==Description== A ''char'' or ''chare'' was a turn (of work) in the sixteenth century,<ref>'Char' in [[Oxford English Dictionary]]</ref> which gave rise to the word being used as a prefix to denote people working in domestic service. The usage of "charwoman" was common in the mid-19th century, often appearing as an occupation in the UK census of 1841, but it fell out of common use in the later decades of the 20th century, often replaced by the term "daily (woman)". Unlike a [[maid]] or [[Housekeeper (domestic worker)|housekeeper]], typically live-in positions, the charwoman usually worked for hourly wages, usually on a part-time basis, often having several different employers.
==Fiction== {{example farm|section|date=April 2017}} The position often features in fiction.
One notable character is Ebeneezer Scrooge's charwoman Mrs. Dilber who appears in [[Charles Dickens]]'s ''[[A Christmas Carol]]''.
In 1926, [[Lord Dunsany]]'s fantasy novel, ''[[The Charwoman's Shadow]]'' was published to good reviews.
Another well-known fictional charwoman is Ada Harris, the central character in [[Paul Gallico]]'s novel ''[[Mrs 'Arris goes to Paris]]'' and its three sequels.
In the British radio comedy series ''[[It's That Man Again]],'' Dorothy Summers played the part of Mrs Mopp, an office char whose catch phrase was "Can I do you now, Sir?" (i.e., "May I clean your office now, Sir?" but with an obvious [[double entendre]]).
A charwoman appears in [[Franz Kafka]]'s ''[[The Metamorphosis]]'' (1915).<ref>{{cite web|title=The Metamorphosis by Franz Kafka|url=http://summarycentral.tripod.com/themetamorphosis.htm|accessdate=5 April 2011}}</ref>
In the short story "The Diary of Anne Rodway", by Wilkie Collins, Anne investigates the murder of her friend Mary and learns that the suspect's wife is a woman "ready to turn her hand to anything: charing, [[laundry|washing]], [[embalming|laying-out]], [[house sitting|keeping empty houses]]...."
A charwoman - Sarah Cobbin - is a critical character in the detective novel, ''Part for a Poisoner'' (1948) by [[ECR Lorac|E.C.R. Lorac]]
Mabel was the lowly charwoman and a main character in the British sitcom [[You Rang, M'Lord?]]
Motion pictures also had their share of charwoman characters. The best example of this is probably the series of films that featured the funny and feisty Irish charwoman Mrs. Riley, a creation of the music hall comedian [[Arthur Lucan]]. The public's enthusiasm for his impromptu stage character prompted him to make her a part of his repertoire and this led to his starring in sixteen [[Old Mother Riley]] films, from 1937 to 1952.
In 1963, [[Peggy Mount]] starred as charwoman Mrs. Cragg in ''[[Ladies Who Do]]'', a film in which a group of charwomen unite and go into high finance under the guidance of the eccentric Colonel Whitforth [[Robert Morley]], in order to save their old neighbourhood from a team of ruthless developers led by [[Harry H. Corbett]].
In 1966-67, actress [[Kathleen Harrison]] starred as Alice Thursday, a charwoman, who inherits ₤10 million from her employer, on the British television series, ''[[Mrs Thursday|Mrs. Thursday]]''.
U.S. comedian [[Carol Burnett]] made a charwoman character into a signature routine during her television career with [[Garry Moore]] and later on her own popular [[The Carol Burnett Show|long-running variety show]].
In the comic strip ''[[Andy Capp]]'', Andy's wife Flo is a charwoman.

The '''Correctional Education Association''' ('''CEA''') was founded in 1930<ref>{{cite journal | last=Robert | first=Mattucci | title=Personal Reflections on Austin MacCormick's 1931 Correctional Education Book: The Integration of Vocational, Academic, and Social Education | journal=Journal of Correctional Education | publisher=Find Articles | date=March 2006 | url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa4111/is_200603/ai_n17175294/pg_1 | format=abstract | accessdate=2007-07-02}}</ref> to provide educational services in correctional settings. This non-profit professional association is the largest affiliate of the [[American Correctional Association]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}}
==Purpose and Goals== The Correctional Education Association is the professional organization for educators who work in adult correctional and juvenile justice facilities internationally. Although based in the United States of America, where most of its members work, it has made great advances in encouraging members from outside the US to become active members from outside the US to become active members of the organization. The CEA provides a host of services to its members. These include the following: a peer-reviewed international journal, a quarterly newsletter, annual membership and resource directory, an accreditation system for prison, jail, and juvenile school programs, a website and listserves for its special interest groups, under-graduate and graduate online courses for educators, and many more services.<ref name="CEANAT">[http://www.ceanational.org www.ceanational.org]</ref>
==History== [[Austin MacCormick]] wrote a book based on the results of his 1928 nationwide survey of prison education (later published in 1931 as a book entitled ''The Education of Adult Prisoners: A Survey and a Program''). MacCormick was influenced by [[Thomas Mott Osborne]] as evidenced by the dedication of his book.<ref>{{cite|title=Review: American Journal of Sociology, vol. 37, No. 5 |author=Review by A. Warren Steams |year=1932 |page=818-820}}</ref>
MacCormick was Assistant Director of the [[Federal Bureau of Prisons|U.S. Bureau of Prisons]], organized in 1930 a standing committee on education within the American Prison Association (now the American Correctional Association). The Standing Committee on Education published its first journal from 1937 to 1940 entitled Correctional Education. In 1945, the Standing Committee on Education organized the Correctional Education Association (CEA) at the 76th Congress of the American Prison Association. In 1946, CEA was formally recognized with Price Chenault elected as the first President. In 1949, The Journal of Correctional Education was reestablished with Chester D. Owens as editor. In 1981, the CEA hired its first Executive Director, Osa Coffey, and established a national office.<ref name="CEANAT" />
In 1986 CEA moved its national office to Maryland from Washington, DC where it remains today. The current address (October 2015) is 12625 Laurel Bowie Road #3430, Laurel, MD 20709. Telephone is 443-459-3080 and the fax number is 443-459-3088. Website: www.ceanational.org. The Acting Executive Director is Morris Dews and the Administrative Assistant is Kiara Wilson.
==Organization== CEA is divided into 8 regions encompassing both the United States and Canada. There are two international representative seats open on the Executive Board of the CEA. There is one representative for Canada and one for the Rest of the World. The International Representatives relay the issues and subjects of concern from international members to the Executive Board at regular meetings.
There are numerous state and provincial chapters. These regions and state/provincial chapters host annual conferences and training seminars. The International CEA has an annual traveling summer conference and hosts an annual Spring Forum. The annual International conferences offer members an opportunity to exchange ideas with correctional and prison educators from around the world and dialogue about the experience of teaching in a unique pedagogical setting. Each year the ''Journal of Correctional Education'' devotes a special issue to a different subject. The June 2007 issue of the ''Journal'' was devoted to international issues in correctional education with contributions from other countries including Ireland and Israel.
The CEA is the largest professional organization dedicated to the mission of education for those students in the Adult and Juvenile Criminal Justice Systems. There are over 1300 members of CEA.<ref name="CEANAT" />
==Standards Commission==
The most current versions of the CEA Standards are listed below: * Performance Standards for Correctional Education Programs in Adult Institutions, July 2016 * Performance Standards for Correctional Education Programs in Juvenile Institutions, July 2010 * Performance Standards for Correctional Education Programs in Jails and Detention Centers, July 2016
