[[File:Rudeshur.jpg|thumb|right|From one of the lowest [[energy intensity]] users in the world in 1980, Iran has become one of the major consumers of energy with very high energy intensity.]] The '''Iranian targeted subsidy plan''' ({{lang-fa|طرح هدفمندسازی یارانه‌ها}}), also known as the '''subsidy reform plan''', was passed by the [[Iranian Parliament]] on January 5, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://previous.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=115408§ionid=351020102 |title=Majlis approves Ahmadinejad's subsidy bill |publisher=Presstv.com |date=2010-01-05 |accessdate=2010-01-30}} The [[Government of Iran|government]] has described the subsidy plan as the "biggest surgery" to the [[Economy of Iran|nation's economy]] in half a century and "one of the most important undertakings in [[Economic history of Iran#After the 1979 revolution|Iran's recent economic history]]".[http://www.presstv.com/detail/157481.html PressTV: 'Subsidy reforms halt fuel consumption']. Retrieved December 30, 2010. The goal of the subsidy reform plan is to replace subsidies on food and [[Energy in Iran|energy]] (80% of total) with targeted social assistance, in accordance with a [[Economy of Iran#National economic planning|Five Year Economic Development Plan]] and a move towards [[free market]] prices in a 5-year period.{{cite web|url=http://www.atiehbahar.com/Resource.aspx?n=1000039 |title=Resources - Economic Indicators |publisher=Atieh Bahar |date=2008-10-20 |accessdate=2010-01-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513034614/http://www.atiehbahar.com/Resource.aspx?n=1000039 |archivedate=2011-05-13 |df= }} The subsidy reform plan is the most important part of a broader [[economy of Iran#Economic reform plan|Iranian economic reform plan]]. According to the government, approximately $100 billion per year is spent on [[energy subsidies|subsidizing energy prices]] ($45 billion for the prices of fuel alone) and many consumable goods including bread, sugar, rice, cooking oil and medicine.{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2010/0430/Why-Iran-s-Ahmadinejad-is-pushing-to-cut-popular-government-subsidies |title=Why Iran's Ahmadinejad is pushing to cut popular government subsidies |work=Christian Science Monitor |date=2010-04-30 |accessdate=2010-05-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3111/html/economy.htm |title=Iran daily: Energy Subsidies Reach $84b |accessdate=2008-04-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080506122659/http://www.iran-daily.com/1387/3111/html/economy.htm |archivedate=May 6, 2008 |df= }}. Retrieved February 13, 2010. However, some experts believe direct subsidies are about $30 billion, depending on [[oil price]]s.{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/wire/sns-ap-iran-nuclear,0,5909101.story |title=Iran may limit cooperation with nuclear watchdog|work=Los Angeles Times |date=2010-12-18 |accessdate=2010-12-23}}[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-09/iran-gasoline-consumption-falls-13-after-government-price-rise.html Bloomberg: Iran Gasoline Consumption Falls 13% After Government Price Rise] Retrieved January 9, 2011 The subsidy system has been inherited from the [[Iran–Iraq War]] era but was never abolished. Iran is one of the largest gasoline consumers in the world, ranking second behind the [[United States]] in consumption per car.[http://www.iran-e-sabz.org/news/iranenv.html United States Energy Information Administration: Environmental Issues in Iran (2000)]. Retrieved August 16, 2009. The government subsidy reform has been [[History of the Islamic Republic of Iran|years in the making for various reasons]].{{cite web|url=http://tehrantimes.com/Index_view.asp?code=209285 |title=President: Opposition to subsidy plan is ‘politically motivated’ |work=Tehran Times |date=2009-12-07 |accessdate=2010-01-30}}{{cite web|url=http://tehrantimes.com/Index_view.asp?code=171486 |title=Majlis special committee to study economic reform plan |publisher=Tehran Times |date=2008-06-24 |accessdate=2010-01-30}}{{cite web |url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/science/258875/irans_third_development_plan_an_appraisal/index.html |title=Iran's Third Development Plan: an Appraisal |accessdate=2010-07-26 |last=Dr. Amuzegar |first=Jahangir |date=2005-10-03}} Iran's [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Supreme Leader]] has backed [[Government of Iran|the government]]'s latest subsidy reform plan.[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/06/world/middleeast/06iran.html ''New York Times'': Supreme Leader in Iran Supports Bid to Cut Subsidies] Retrieved January 6, 2011 ==Objectives== {{See also|Iranian Economic Reform Plan|Energy in Iran|2007 Gasoline Rationing Plan in Iran#Fuel smuggling|l3=Fuel smuggling in Iran}} [[File:Mercedes bus and Samand.jpg|right|thumb|According to the Iranian government, $100 billion is spent on subsidies each year. The reform plan aims to encourage [[public transport]] by decreasing fuel subsidies.]] Iran was the largest provider of fuel subsidies in the world by 2009. Many Iranian experts agree that these unsustainable subsidies encourage waste among goods, including in the production sector, ranging from [[gasoline]] to bread that must be stopped and the only way to do that is to redirect subsidies.{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L-_ZhtS4wws |title=Press TV- Iran Today- President Ahmadinejads economy reform plan-01-08-2010- (Part 1) |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-01-09 |accessdate=2010-01-30}} The stated goal of the subsidy reform is "to rejuvenate Iran's economy, increase productivity, give it a new footing and bring it out of the slump it has been in for so long". Concretely, the government plans to replace the subsidies with targeted [[social assistance]]. Consequences of the economic reform plan are that Iran will be less vulnerable to [[sanctions against Iran|US sanctions]] because it will reduce fuel imports.[http://www.tehrantimes.com/index.php/economy-and-business/3700-iran-gasoline-import-slump-softens-sanctions Tehran Times: Iran gasoline import slump softens sanctions]. Retrieved October 20, 2011.[http://www.economist.com/node/17900396?story_id=17900396&fsrc=rss The Economist: The regime tightens its belt and its fist] Retrieved January 17, 2011 The reform plan will also save money for the Iranian people because it will end a [[2007 Gas Rationing Plan in Iran#Fuel smuggling|multibillion-dollar-a-year contraband]] (17% percent of fuel production in Iran is smuggled abroad daily).[http://www.tehrantimes.com/index.php/economy-and-business/92800-subsidy-reform-plan-saves-iran-6b-minister Subsidy reform plan saves Iran $6b: minister]. ''Tehran Times''. Retrieved December 5, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://previous.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=107132§ionid=351020103 |title='17 percent of daily fuel production smuggled abroad' |publisher=Presstv.com |date=2009-09-26 |accessdate=2010-01-30}}[http://rand.org/pubs/monographs/2008/RAND_MG821.pdf RAND Corporation: The Rise of the Pasdaran]. Retrieved June 10, 2010. Due to subsidies, Iran had long had one of the cheapest gas prices in the world, 10 cents per liter or 40 cents per gallon. Implementation of the plan will reduce waste and [[consumerism]]. In fact, according to official data, the [[Social class in Iran#The upper class|higher income strata]] of the population has enjoyed the same subsidies as the poor until now. On the other side, subsidies reduction will reduce air pollution by reducing car traffic in [[Tehran#Pollution|Tehran]].[http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/survey/so/2010/INT092810A.htm IMF: Iran to Cut Oil Subsidies in Energy Reform]. Retrieved October 13, 2010. Finally, the subsidy plan will increase [[social justice]] through targeted social assistance.[http://www.tehrantimes.com/index.php/economy-and-business/2830-subsidy-plan-reduces-poverty-and-income-disparities-in-iran-world-bank Subsidy plan reduces poverty and income disparities in Iran: World Bank] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111230132429/http://www.tehrantimes.com/index.php/economy-and-business/2830-subsidy-plan-reduces-poverty-and-income-disparities-in-iran-world-bank |date=2011-12-30 }}. Tehran Times. Retrieved October 19, 2011. According to official data, the richest decile of households benefits 12 times more from gasoline subsidies than the poorest decile.{{cite web|url=http://go.worldbank.org/KQD2RP3RX0 |title=Iran - Country Brief |publisher=Go.worldbank.org |accessdate=2010-01-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070503235931/http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/COUNTRIES/MENAEXT/IRANEXTN/0,,menuPK:312966~pagePK:141132~piPK:141107~theSitePK:312943,00.html |archivedate=2007-05-03 |df= }} Overall, implementation of the plan will ''increase'' [[productivity]], [[Energy conversion efficiency|efficiency]], [[Global Competitiveness Report|competitiveness of Iran's economy]], [[Central Bank of Iran#GDP growth|economic growth]], [[Petroleum industry in Iran|oil exports]] and [[per capita income]] (all other things being equal).{{cite web|url=http://previous.presstv.com/classic/detail.aspx?id=110912§ionid=3510303 |title=Targeted Subsidies in Iran |publisher=Press TV |accessdate=2010-01-30}}[http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/scr/2010/cr1074.pdf Islamic Republic of Iran: IMF Staff Report] Retrieved March 9, 2011 ==Implementation== {{See also|Supreme Audit Court of Iran}} [[File:Iran subsidies reform plan2.png|thumb|right|Iran wants to save up to $100 billion on subsidies within three to four years.]] For implementation of the bill, an entity has been established as a duly authorized governmental company under the name "Targeting Subsidies Organization".[http://www.nourlaw.com/newsletter/newsletter.html#_The_Bill_for_Subsidy_Targeting_Ready_for_President’s_Implementation Nourlaw.com: The Bill for Subsidy Targeting Ready for President’s Implementation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119032803/http://www.nourlaw.com/newsletter/newsletter.html |date=2012-01-19 }}. Retrieved June 10, 2010. The amount saved by the government, will be distributed as follows: 50% towards the [[economy of Iran#Labor and welfare|poorest strata of Iranian society]]; 20% at the government's disposal (to compensate for increased costs or as [[safety net]]); and the remaining 30% will be directed towards improving the efficiency of the utility, fuel and energy production infrastructure, [[Transport in Iran|public transportation]] development, [[Economy of Iran#Manufacturing|industry]] and [[Agriculture in Iran|farming]]. The plan will commence with energy, fuel and utilities in the first year and consumable goods will start in the second year. The start of the cuts will coincide with the beginning of the second half of the [[Iranian calendar|Iranian year]] on Sept. 23, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-05-13/iranian-subsidy-cuts-to-begin-in-september-ahmadinejad-says.html |title=Iranian Subsidy Cuts to Begin in September, Ahmadinejad Says |work=Businessweek |date=2010-05-13 |accessdate=2010-05-26 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} At that time, the [[2007 Gasoline Rationing Plan in Iran|2007 Gas rationing plan]] will come to an end.[http://previous.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=129294§ionid=351020103 PressTV: Iran plans to cut subsidized fuel]. Retrieved June 7, 2010. ===Budgeting=== {{see also|Government of Iran#Public finance and fiscal policy|Ministry of Petroleum (Iran)|l1=Public finance and fiscal policy in Iran}} In March 2010, the [[Iranian Parliament]] approved a $347 billion budget, in which the allocation from subsidies and the [[oil price]] were set at $20 billion and $65 per barrel, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://previous.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=120362§ionid=351020102 |title=Iran Parliament approves $347 billion budget |publisher=Presstv.com |accessdate=2010-03-09}}{{cite news|author=Reza Derakhshi |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6274XD20100308 |title=Iran parliament approves Ahmadinejad budget |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-02-09 |accessdate=2010-03-09}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-12-19/iran-cuts-energy-subsidies-as-sanctions-take-toll.html |title=Iran Cuts Energy Subsidies as Sanctions Take Toll |work=BusinessWeek |date=2010-12-19 |accessdate=2010-12-23}} According to the Vice President for Parliamentary Affairs, Iran's subsidy reforms would save 20 percent of the country's budget.[http://www.presstv.com/detail/152977.html PressTV: 'Subsidy cut saves Iran 20% on budget']. Retrieved March 16, 2011. Iran wants to save up to $100 billion on subsidies within three to four years.{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/10/jan/1226.html |title=Iran: Ahmadinejad Submits Ambitious Budget |work=Payvand |date=2006-11-22 |accessdate=2010-01-30}}{{cite news|last=Derakhshi |first=Reza |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2010/01/03/uk-iran-subsidies-bill-idUKTRE6020FT20100103 |title=Iran MPs reject call for subsidy bill withdrawal |publisher=Reuters |date= 2010-01-03|accessdate=2010-01-30}} In 2011, the Iranian parliament approved a $508 billion budget based on $80/barrel [[oil price]]. This bill also factors in $54 billion from price hikes and subsidy cuts. [[File:Iranoilandgas.jpg|thumb|right|Iran's oil and gas projected revenues by the [[International Monetary Fund]]. Iranian officials estimate that [[Petroleum industry in Iran|Iran's annual oil and gas revenues]] could reach as much as $250 billion by 2015.[http://www.payvand.com/news/10/dec/1216.html Mehr News Agency: Iran eyes $250 billion annual revenue in 5 years]. Retrieved December 22, 2010.]] [[File:IRAN GDP.jpg|right|thumb|Iran's [[Central Bank of Iran#GDP growth|GDP projections]], 1999-2015 est.]] {| class="wikitable" |+[[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] Projections/Scenarios |- ! !! as at 2008/09!! 2014/15

|| 38.7% |- |Budget for State-Owned Banks and Enterprises || 355 || 252.5 || 40.6% |- | Total* || '''508''' || '''368.4''' || '''37.9%''' |- | Resources from Subsidies Phase Out|| 54 || 20 || 171.7% |} * Totals may not add up due to rounding and deduction of double-counted items Note: all numbers are in billion dollars. ===Income data=== {{see also|Labor and tax laws in Iran}} [[File:Tajrishbazar.JPG|thumb|right|According to the [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]], until recently a four-member Iranian household received an average of $4,000 a year in subsidies for oil and natural gas, compared with a typical annual income of about $3,600 a year.]] According to the IMF, until recently a four-member Iranian household received an average of $4,000 a year in subsidies for oil and natural gas, compared with a typical annual income of about $3,600 a year.{{cite web|url=http://www.iran-daily.com/1389/7/8/MainPaper/3789/Page/1/index.htm# |title=No. 3789 | Front page | Page 1 |publisher=Irandaily |date=2010-09-30 |accessdate=2010-10-08}} In 2010, Iran's Department of Statistics announced that 10 million Iranians live under the [[Absolute poverty|absolute poverty line]] and 30 million live under the [[Relative poverty|relative poverty line]].[http://www.payvand.com/news/10/may/1316.html Radio Zamaneh: Ten Million Iranians Under "Absolute Poverty Line"] Retrieved May 28, 2010 President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] says implementation of the targeted subsidy system will eradicate [[economy of Iran#Labor and welfare|unemployment and poverty in Iran]] within three years. ====Data collection==== {{See also|Social Security Organization (Iran)|Privatization in Iran#"Justice shares" plan|l2="Justice shares" distribution in Iran}} The administration has said earlier that it will be able to allocate different payment amounts to different people. To that end, in 2009, forms were distributed asking Iranians to report income, assets and property but the question remains on how the government will verify this information gathered by self-reporting. Many people have chosen not to report or withhold information. The administration has categorized the people into three income brackets; namely lower, middle, and higher for the implementation of the subsidy reform plan.[http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=213503 Tehran Times: 40 percent of families in lower income bracket]. Retrieved February 2, 2010. On the other side, it was not clear in what form the compensation would be distributed, direct cash or goods. Another concern is the accuracy of government information on [[disposable income|family incomes]]. In September 2010, Iran's Statistics Bureau announced that implementation was delayed by one month because they were still collecting information regarding the financial situation of households and opening bank accounts for them.{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/10/sep/1208.html |title=Iran delays government subsidy reform again |work=Payvand |date=2006-11-22 |accessdate=2010-10-08}} ===Plan revision=== {{see also|Banking and insurance in Iran}} Later in 2010, the government announced that it had revised its plan because of lack of reliable data on personal incomes. To ease the economic loss from lost subsidies, the government indicated it would distribute $40 per person/month (i.e. 455,000 rials/month) to 90% of the general population, starting on December 18, 2010.[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704506404575592302978213006?reflink=barrons_redirect Wall Street Journal: Iran Tightens Security as Subsidy Cuts Loom]. $4 billion for government to cover increased costs) || >$10 billion for production |} ===Price adjustments=== {{see also|Central Bank of Iran#Inflation and monetary policy|l1=Inflation and monetary policy in Iran}} [[File:Inflation-Iran.png|thumb|right|Between 2002 and 2006, the rate of inflation in [[Iran]] has been fluctuating between 12 and 16%{{cite web|url=http://www.indexmundi.com/iran/inflation_rate_(consumer_prices).html|title=Iran Inflation Rate|publisher=index Mondi}}]] The government took control of [[Price control|deciding how much the prices should rise in a year]], as long as the subsidy cuts on gasoline and other refined products, natural gas, electricity, water, food (sugar, rice, cooking oil and bread), health and education are between $10 and 20 billion dollars annually. Estimates indicate that the government has to increase existing prices by an average of 2.5 times to achieve the lower target and by 4 times for the maximum target. According to the IMF, Iranians can expect the first price hike to lift energy product prices between four and 20 times previous levels, with prices surging even higher eventually.{{cite web|url=http://www.iran-daily.com/1389/7/8/MainPaper/3789/Page/1/index.htm# |title=Cutting Subsidies To Boost Efficiency: Report From IMF Economists |publisher=Iran-daily.com |date=2010-09-30 |accessdate=2010-10-08}} ====Other determinants==== {{see also|Agriculture in Iran}} According to the plan, the type of consumption (i.e. whether agricultural, industrial and civil) will also be considered when setting energy prices. The subsidy plan will be implemented in proportion with [[Geography of Iran|geographical regions]] because warm regions consume more electricity during summer while cold regions consume more gas during winter. Finally, the time of consumption (i.e. during peak and off-peak hours) and the [[Energy in Iran|consumption demand]] (i.e. whether it is low or high) will be taken into consideration. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Financial Times. Retrieved April 25, 2012. Retrieved August 1, 2012.[http://www.chron.com/news/article/Report-Rare-Iran-protest-over-food-price-hikes-3728470.php "Report: Rare Iran protest over food price hikes."] ''AP'', 23 July 2012. Retrieved August 1, 2012 ===Consumption patterns=== {{See also|Demography of Iran}} As of October 2011, consumption of liquefied petroleum gas, gasoline, kerosene, and diesel has cut between 4 and 19%, despite the fact that more than 1 million cars have been added to Iran's fleet. Increased use of compressed natural gas ([[CNG]]) to fuel cars has also reportedly played a role in this. According to the government, if oil products consumption had not been managed, consumption of gasoline would have increased to 120 million liters per day, while by reforming consumption pattern the figure has fallen to 60 million liters per day. In November 2011, the Government reported that the subsidy reform plan has saved Iran $6 billion. Retrieved October 30, 2010. Experts believe that following the launch of the subsidies reform plan, the [[List of power stations in Iran|electricity industry]] will undergo significant changes and will become more appealing to private investors.[http://www.turquoisepartners.com/iraninvestment/IIM-Mar11.pdf Turquoise Partners: Iran Investment Monthly (March 2011)] Retrieved April 30, 2011. On the other side, the [[Mining in Iran#Cement|cement industry in Iran]] is one of the [[economy of Iran#Sectors of the economy|economic sectors]] that will be hit the hardest in Iran following of the subsidy reform plan, because many Iranian cement factories are energy inefficient (Notwithstanding possible [[Ministry of Commerce (Iran)|Ministry of Commerce]] adjustment and/or liberalization of commodities prices by the government during implementation).{{cite web|url=http://www.turquoisepartners.com/iraninvestment/IIM-Oct10.pdf|format=pdf|access-date=2018-02-19|publisher=Turquoise Partners|title=Iran Investmnet Monthly|page=6}} Taxi, delivery and [[truck driver]]s have also been adversely affected by the recent gas price increase.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/middle-east/101220/iran-subsidy-cuts-economic-sanctions |title=Iran | Economy | Sanctions |publisher=Globalpost.com |accessdate=2011-01-06}} Experts believe that the removal of subsidies is likely to have an adverse impact on the profitability of the [[Iranian automobile industry|automotive sector]] for at least the next 2–3 years. One major element of pressure on producers is the [[Iranian rial#Value|unchanged exchange regime]] of the [[Central Bank of Iran]], which puts imported products at an advantage by failing to compensate for the relative increase in production costs of domestic producers. ===Second phase=== {{See also|Social class in Iran}} During the second phase, starting in June 2012, half of the funds from energy and food subsidies will be re-allocated to the people and the remaining 50% will go to the industrial sector. If approved by the Parliament, the government will pay an ''extra'' cash handout of 280,000 [[Iranian rial|rials]]/month to 80% of the general population (i.e. people earning less than $2000/month, which is a comfortable income level in Iran).[http://presstv.com/Program/236153.html Second Phase of Subsidy Reform: Concerted efforts of Government and People]. PressTV. Retrieved April 18, 2012. In July 2012, it was announced that implementation of the second phase was suspended awaiting further adjustments by the government and because of raising inflation (around 22% as of April 2012). Finally, in fall 2013, the parliament approved a plan to drop 22 million Iranians—the top 30 percent of earners—from the subsidy system instead.[http://www.voanews.com/content/irans-budget-2014-taking-shape/1840387.html Iran's 2014 Budget Taking Shape]. Voice of America, January 29, 2014. Retrieved February 1, 2014. Yet, it was reported in 2014 that out of Iran’s population of 77 million, 73.6 million registered to receive the cash hand-outs.[http://www.turquoisepartners.com/iraninvestment/IIM-AprMay14.pdf Iran Investment Monthly]. Turquoise Partners, April 2014, Retrieved June 21, 2014. ==Effects and criticism== ===2010=== According to earlier critics, even if half of $20 billion is passed as part of the compensation to the poorer 50% of the [[Demography of Iran|Iranian society]], it will amount to $25 per eligible person per month; "no way near enough to make up for such inflation rates". Critics say that if the government goes for the top of this range [[Central Bank of Iran#Inflation and monetary policy|inflation]] could rise up to 40% through the economy.{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5lI9zc0QQrc |title=Presstv |publisher=Youtube.com |date=2010-01-09 |accessdate=2010-01-30}} The [[International Monetary Fund]], however, has predicted a more moderate rise in inflation of just 32 percent.[http://www.payvand.com/news/10/jun/1083.html RFE/RL/Payvand.com: Sanctions And Iran's Achilles Heel]. Retrieved June 11, 2010. As of January 2010, the official inflation rate stands at 15 percent. The [[cost of living]] in Iran, according to the [[Strategic Majlis Research Center|Majlis Research Center]], could rise by up to 60 percent.[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/tehranbureau/2010/10/irans-subsidies-conundrum.html PBS-Iran Primer: The Subsidies Conundrum]. Retrieved October 26, 2010. Ahmadinejad's administration contends that the negative side effects will be transient and that the projections are based on out-of-date [[economic model|models]].{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/tehranbureau/2010/09/irans-subsidies-conundrum.html |title=FRONTLINE: Tehran Bureau: Iran's Subsidies Conundrum |publisher=PBS |accessdate=2010-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101003102927/http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/tehranbureau/2010/09/irans-subsidies-conundrum.html |archivedate=October 3, 2010 }} ===2011=== According to some western reports, cash payments have been denied to some opponents of the regime during the distribution phase.Tait, Robert. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/library/news/iran/2010/iran-101220-rferl01.htm "Economists Say Iran Subsidy Plan A Weapon Of Political Control."] ''[[Radio Liberty]]'', 20 December 2010. [[Ahmad Tavakkoli]], a parliamentarian, accused the government of “violating the law” and “mis-implementing” the plan because it earned 290,000bn rials ($23.6bn) from the cut in subsidies in the first 14 months of its implementation but paid people $36.7bn of compensation in return (he says). It has also been reported that while the subsidy reform plan needs further adaptation and fine-tuning, citizens must separate the questions of [[public policy]] from the issues of government legitimacy.[http://www.payvand.com/news/11/jan/1031.html Nader Habibi: Reaction to Iranian Government's Subsidy Reform Program]. Retrieved April 6, 2011. The IMF has hailed Iran's economic reform and asked Iran's expertise to be transferred to other countries.{{cite web|url=http://presstv.com/detail/175246.html |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.com |accessdate=2012-08-15}} The [[Economist Intelligence Unit]] has also praised Iran's subsidies reform plan for its positive effect on the economy in 2011.{{Cite news|title=Economic jihad|url=http://www.economist.com/node/18867440|publisher=The Economist|date=2011-06-23}} ===2012=== In 2012, Iran's head of the [[Expediency Council]], Ayatollah [[Hashemi Rafsanjani]], criticized the government for failing to reinvest the money it saved by restructuring government subsidies. To compensate, the government says it has allowed producers to [[liberalization|adjust their prices more liberally]] and it has given free loans and energy subsidies in some cases.[http://www.turquoisepartners.com/iraninvestment/IIM-Jan12.pdf Iran Investment Monthly.] Turquoise Partners, January 2012. Retrieved February 16, 2012.[http://www.payvand.com/news/12/jan/1326.html Rafsanjani criticizes Ahmadinejad's economic policies]. Radio Zamaneh. Retrieved February 11, 2012. In recent years, income inequality in Iran has declined by different measures, which may be an effect of the subsidy reforms. For example, the income [[Gini coefficient]] fell from 0.4023 in 2005 to 0.3813 in 2010. Between February 2011 and February 2012, the government earned 510 trillion rials (some $41.6 billion) by implementing the Subsidy Reform Plan. According to the [[World Bank]]:[http://presstv.com/detail/222589.html Iran's economy to grow in 2012: WB]. PressTV. Retrieved February 4, 2012. {{Quote box |quote = A revision to the system of subsidies and cash transfers to better balance reimbursements and fiscal accounts has been looked upon favorably by outside analysts. Iran has made important efforts to reform its income support system away from subsidies and toward better targeted social safety nets, and this has brought down the pace of prices. |source = |align = left |width = 100% |fontsize = 100% |bgcolor = AliceBlue |style = |title_bg = |title_fnt = |tstyle = text-align: left; |qalign = left |qstyle = text-align: left; |quoted = yes |salign = right |sstyle = text-align: right;}} In October 2012, 179 of 240 members of parliament voted in favor of pausing the subsidy reform, because of high inflation (exacerbated by the [[sanctions against Iran]]).Torbati, Yeganeh. [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/07/us-iran-economy-idUSBRE8950B320121007 "Iran parliament may halt Ahmadinejad economic policy."] ''Reuters'', 7 October 2012. Consequently, the growth in consumption of subsidized products rebounded in 2012.[http://www.tehrantimes.com/economy-and-business/116940-irans-subsidy-reform-a-successful-example-of-income-distribution-imf Iran's subsidy reform a successful example of income distribution: IMF]. {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714234116/http://www.tehrantimes.com/economy-and-business/116940-irans-subsidy-reform-a-successful-example-of-income-distribution-imf# |date=2014-07-14 }} ''Tehran Times'', July 12, 2014. Retrieved July 2014. ===2014=== In 2014, Iran started the second phase of its targeted subsidy plan under President [[Hassan Rohani]]. Petrol prices were raised by 75% from 4,000 to 7,000 rials ($0.16 to $0.28) per litre,[https://www.economist.com/blogs/pomegranate/2014/04/iran Iran: Cut those subsidies. ''The Economist'', April 30, 2014. Retrieved March 13, 2015] which is far from the [[2007 Gasoline Rationing Plan in Iran#Prices in neighboring countries|target price of approx. $0.90 per litre]]. As a consequence, fuel smuggling and [[National Iranian Oil Refining and Distribution Company#Fuel imports|gasoline imports]] increased again.[http://presstv.com/Detail/2015/09/06/427959/Iran-gasoline-imports-double-in-6-months Iran gasoline imports double in 6 months]. PressTV, September 6, 2015. Retrieved September 8, 2015. ===2015=== Iran's government reported that the second phase of the subsidy reform plan will continue as originally planned. ===2016=== According to the [[Economy of Iran#National economic planning|sixth five-year development plan]] (2016-2021), the subsidy reform plan is to be extended until 2021, eventhough this delay in the implementation runs contrary to the Parliament's ratification of the law on subsidies reform.{{cite news| title= Rouhani presents $262b budget bill to Majlis| work = Tehran Times Social Desk | url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/news/252294/Rouhani-presents-262b-budget-bill-to-Majlis| date= January 18, 2016| accessdate=January 24, 2016| publisher=[[Tehran Times]]}} In 2016, the [[Iranian Parliament]] approved subsidy cuts to 24 Million Iranians. Under the changes, the government must end monthly cash payments of around $12 a person for many government employees with income above $900 per month and citizens who already receive social welfare.[http://www.payvand.com/news/16/apr/1059.html Iranian Parliament Approves Subsidy Cuts To 24 Million Iranians.] RFE/RL. 14 April 2016. Retrieved May 26, 2016. Nevertheless, the government is said to be reluctant to comply because this would be "unfair" despite the risk of running large [[Government of Iran#Budget|budget deficits]].[http://tehrantimes.com/news/300761/Gov-says-cannot-cut-cash-subsidies-to-24-million-citizens Government says cannot cut cash subsidies to 24 million citizens]. Tehran Times, 19 April 2016. Retrieved May 26, 2016. More recently the government has announced that it will scrap the subsidy reform plan because of "inflationary pressures" and replace it with a new plan named "energy management". The new plan aims to set new higher fuel prices (as in the original plan - consequently economize on energy consumption and increase production efficiency).[http://iran-daily.com/News/170018.html Subsidy reform plan problematic]. Iran Daily, October 8, 2016. Retrieved October 10, 2016. Even though cash subsidies were intended for 10% of the general population originally, they were given to 90% of the population, mostly because of lack of political will and lack of accurate data on people's income. Those cash handouts "discouraged people to work in rural areas" the government has also argued , although this claim is not supported by an Economic Research Forum study that found no evidence of labor supply reductions, but did find increases in hours worked among service sector workers, possibly due to business expansions made possible by the increased cash.[http://erf.org.eg/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/1090.pdf] Salehi-Isfahani, Djavad, and Mohammad Mostafavi-Dehzooei (2017) ‘Cash Transfers and Labor Supply: Evidence From a Large-Scale Program in Iran’, ERF Working Paper No. 1090. ==See also== {{Portal|Iran|Business and economics}} * [[Economy of Iran]] * [[Economic history of Iran]] * [[Social Security Organization (Iran)]] * [[Transition economy]] * [[International rankings of Iran]] * [[Iran and WTO]] * [[Tehran Stock Exchange]] * [[Chinese economic reform]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.economist.com/node/18867440 Iran's bold economic reform - {{Orphan|date=September 2018}}
'''Joro the Paver''', also known as the '''Bulgarian Jack the Ripper''', is a [[serial rapist]] and murderer from the Konyovitsa neighborhood, who operated in [[Sofia]] in 1968.
In the span of a few months, between 6 and 7 rapes occurred, as a result of which a 69-year-old woman died in hospital. The nickname "Joro the Paver" comes from the [[Pavement (architecture)|paver]] found on the scene, wrapped up in [[handkerchief]] next to one of the victims.<ref>Karolina Tserovska, "[http://archive.is/uIzZ Creepy! The Bulgarian Jack the Ripper is still alive and still stalks women!"], razkritia.com, April 21, 2007</ref>
The deaf and mute Milcho Milanov, from [[Rakita, Sofia Province|Rakita]], was accused of being the perpetrator and arrested by police. Although he was sentenced and spent a significant amount of time in prison, he was later released due to lack of evidence.<ref>Krum Blagov, "[http://paper.standartnews.com/bg/article.php?d=2007-09-29&article=205333 Joro the Paver became a shepherd]", in "Standard", September 29, 2007.</ref>
In the beginning of the 1970s, a new rapist occurred, known as '''"Joro the Paver, the Second"''', who raped 10 victims and committed a double murder. In 1975, the perpetrator Georgi Yordanov was captured, [[sentenced to death]] and subsequently [[executed by firing squad]].
Joro the Paver's true identity remains unknown, and it is also theorised that some rapes in later years have been his doing.
== References == {{reflist}}

{{other people}} {{Infobox person | name = Judy Clare Clarke | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1952}} | birth_place = [[Asheville, North Carolina]] | education = [[Furman University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[University of South Carolina School of Law]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]) | occupation = Criminal Defense Attorney | parents = Harry Wilson Clarke & Patsy Clarke | spouse = Thomas H. Speedy Rice | website = {{URL|https://www.cjtrlaw.com/judy-clarke.html}} }} '''Judy Clare Clarke''' (born 1952) is an American [[Criminal defense lawyer|criminal defense attorney]] who has represented several high-profile defendants. She has negotiated [[plea bargain|plea agreements]] that spare her clients the death penalty, as was the case for [[Eric Rudolph]], [[Ted Kaczynski]], and [[Jared Lee Loughner]]. In the case of [[Susan Smith]], Clarke argued to the jury that ultimately voted against imposing the death penalty. Raised in [[Asheville, North Carolina]], Clarke is a graduate of [[T.C. Roberson High School]], [[Furman University]] and [[University of South Carolina School of Law]]. Clarke served as executive director of the Federal Defenders of San Diego, Inc. (FDSDI) and the Federal Defenders of the Eastern District of Washington and Idaho. From 1996 to 1997, she served as President of the [[National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers]]. Clarke received the John Frank Award from the [[9th Circuit Court of Appeals]].{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=Kristina|title=Judy Clarke honored for death penalty work|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2015/jul/02/judy-clarke-9th-circuit-award-death-penalty/|publisher=SD Union Tribune|accessdate=4 July 2015}} ==Family and education== Judy Clare Clarke is the daughter of Harry Wilson Clarke and Patsy Clarke.{{cite web|last1=Daly|first1=Michael|title=Judy Clarke, the Defense Lawyer Appointed to Defend Dzhokhar Tsarnaev|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/05/01/judy-clarke-the-defense-lawyer-appointed-to-defend-dzhokhar-tsarnaev.html|website=Daily Beast|accessdate=2015-04-03}} Patsy Clarke was the daughter of a Massachusetts movie theater manager who moved the family to Asheville when Patsy was a teen. Her parents met while in college together. Clarke grew up in [[Asheville, North Carolina]]. Growing up, she had three other siblings: Candy, Mark, and one other.{{cite web|last1=Hewitt|first1=Bill|title=A Mother's Anger: Honoring a Son Dead of AIDS, a North Carolina Woman Takes on Jesse Helms|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20142675,00.html|website=People|accessdate=25 December 2014}} Her father was a civic leader in [[Asheville]] and president of Western Carolina Industries employer association. Her mother spent much of her time raising her four children and occasionally acted in regional theater productions.{{cite web|last1=Morrison|first1=Clarke|title=Boston bombing suspect's lawyer is death-penalty foe|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/01/boston-marathon-bombing-lawyer/2126299/|website=USA Today|accessdate=25 December 2014}} Clarke's parents were conservative Republicans. Her father campaigned for Senator [[Jesse Helms]]. In 1987, her father, Harry, was killed in the crash of a private plane near [[Asheville]].{{cite web|title=Plane Crash Kills Pilot|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1454&dat=19870310&id=CeEyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2RMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4545,4518699|website=Google News|publisher=Star-News|accessdate=28 December 2014}} [[Jesse Helms]] called Patsy Clarke to offer his condolences and sent the family a flag that had been flown in his honor at the U.S. Capitol. From about the sixth or seventh grade, Clarke wanted to be a lawyer or a judge. As a child, her mother taught her the [[Constitution]] and she remained interested in it. Moreover, Clarke regularly argued her opinions on current events at the big table her father installed in the family's kitchen. Her parents encouraged independent thinking. For college, Clarke studied psychology at [[Furman University]] in [[Greenville, South Carolina]]. She graduated from Furman in 1974.{{cite web|title=Judy Clarke for the Defense|url=http://newspress.furman.edu/2013/05/judy-clarke-for-the-defense/|website=Furman.edu|accessdate=25 December 2014}} Right after college, Clarke went to the [[University of South Carolina School of Law]] and received her [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] in 1977. In the early 1990s, her brother Mark was diagnosed HIV-positive and revealed to Judy and his mother that he was gay. Mark, at the time, was studying law at [[California Western School of Law]] in San Diego, California. In 1994, Clarke's brother, Mark, died of [[AIDS]]. After seeing [[Jesse Helms]] attacking gay people on the floor of the Senate and trying to block funding for further AIDS research, Patsy Clarke wrote him a letter to ask him to be kind to those who were dying or had died of AIDS.{{cite web|title=AIDS and Jesse Helms|url=http://www.ralphmag.org/AT/jesse-helms.html|website=ralphmag.org|publisher=Ralph Mag|accessdate=28 December 2014}} Jesse Helms responded in a letter: "I know Mark's death was a devastating blow to you. As far as homosexuality, the Bible judges it, I do not. As for Mark, I wish he had not played Russian roulette with his sexual activity. I have sympathy for him and for you. But there is no escaping the reality of what happened." After this, Judy persuaded her mother to come out against their longtime family friend, Sen. [[Jesse Helms]].{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/05/12/183239033/attorney-for-notorious-clients-a-quiet-defender |title=Bombing Suspect's Lawyer A Quiet Defender Of The Notorious |publisher=Npr.org |date=2013-05-12 |accessdate=2015-04-03}} Patsy Clarke and Eloise Vaughn—an equally well-connected conservative in North Carolina politics and one who had also lost a son to AIDS—created MAJIC, Mothers Against Jesse in Congress. They opposed him vigorously in the 1996 election, but he ultimately won re-election. ==Legal career== Right after law school, she moved to [[San Diego]], [[California]] to work as a trial attorney for the Federal Defenders of San Diego, Inc. (FDSDI).{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=Kevin|title=Judy Clarke has a knack for keeping her notorious clients off death row|url=http://www.abajournal.com/magazine/article/judy_clarke_has_a_knack_for_keeping_her_clients_off_death_row|website=ABA Journal|accessdate=25 December 2014}} She was quickly promoted to Senior Trial Attorney and Chief Trial Attorney. From 1983 until 1991, Clarke served as the executive director of FDSDI.{{cite web|title=Our History|url=http://www.fdsdi.com/our_history.html|website=Federal Defenders of San Diego|accessdate=25 December 2014}} During her tenure as executive director, [[federal sentencing guidelines]] were created, a product of the [[Sentencing Reform Act]] of 1984. She argued ''United States v. Rojas-Contreras'' (1985) and ''[[United States v. Munoz-Flores]]'' (1990) before the [[Supreme Court of the United States]].{{cite web|title=Judy Clarke Profile|url=http://www2.oyez.org/advocates/c/j/judy_clare_clarke|website=Oyez.org|accessdate=2015-04-03}} In 1992, Clarke left FDSDI to lead the newly created federal defender office in the Eastern District of Washington and Idaho, which she did until June 2002.{{cite web|last1=Wilkens|first1=John|title=S.D. attorney focuses on clients, not notoriety of cases: Judy Clark, appointed Monday to represent Jared Loughner, might be the most low-profile high-profile attorney in the country|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2011/jan/10/sd-attorney-focuses-on-clients-not-notoriety-of/|website=U~T San Diego|accessdate=25 December 2014}} From 2002-2009, she served as the first full-time Capital Resource Counsel for the Federal Public and Community Defender Program.{{cite web|title=Judy Clarke Profile|url=https://www.capdefnet.org/FDPRC/pubContent.aspx?id=2328|website=Capdefnet.org|accessdate=31 December 2014}} She is currently in private practice in [[San Diego, California]] with her husband, Thomas H. Speedy Rice.{{cite web|title=Clarke & Rice, Attorneys at Law|url=http://jcsrlaw.net/|accessdate=31 December 2014}} In addition, Clarke previously served as President of the [[National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers]]. She was the first public defender president and the second woman president.{{cite web|last1=NACDL - News Release|title=Judy Clarke Elected First Public Defender President|url=http://www.nacdl.org/newsreleases.aspx?id=19235|website=NACDL.org|publisher=NACDL|accessdate=31 December 2014}} Clarke is a member of the Federal Death Penalty Resource Counsel, which helps judges recruit qualified federal public defenders.{{cite web|title=The Federal Death Penalty Resource Counsel|url=https://www.capdefnet.org/fdprc/|website=Capdefnet.org|accessdate=2015-04-03}} She is a fellow of the [[American College of Trial Lawyers]].{{cite web|title=Clarke Listing|url=http://www.actl.com/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home|website=Nactl.org|accessdate=31 December 2014}} Clarke worked as a visiting Professor of Law at [[Washington and Lee University]] from 2006–07 and a Professor of Practice from 2008–09 and in the spring 2010.{{cite web|title=W&L Faculty Profile|url=http://law.wlu.edu/faculty/profiledetail.asp?id=209|publisher=Law.wlu.edu|accessdate=3 January 2015}} ===Susan Smith=== In 1995, she took a leave of absence to serve as co-counsel for [[Susan Smith]], the [[South Carolina]] woman who faced the death penalty in [[South Carolina Circuit Court]] for killing her two sons. Her co-counsel was [[David Bruck]], a friend of hers from law school.{{cite news|last1=Bragg|first1=Rick|title=Arguments Begin in Susan Smith Trial|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/19/us/arguments-begin-in-susan-smith-trial.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=25 December 2014}} In her opening statement, Clarke argued Smith was deeply troubled and suffering from severe depression. She told the jury: "This is not a case about evil.This is a case about despair and sadness." Clarke, however, conceded that Smith knew what she did was wrong, and it tortured her. Clarke pointed out the tragedies in [[Susan Smith]]'s life that included being molested by her stepfather, the suicide of her father and her own suicide attempts—twice when Smith was in her teens. The defense's theory of the case was that Smith drove to the edge of the lake to kill herself and her two sons, but her body willed itself out of the car. The prosecution, on the other hand, believed Smith murdered her children in order to start a new life with a former lover. It only took the jury two and a half hours to convict her of murdering her two sons. Tommy Pope, the lead prosecutor in the Smith case, argued passionately in favor of sentencing Smith to death. But the jury ultimately voted against imposing the death penalty.{{cite news|last1=O'Neill|first1=Ann|title=Lawyer keeps even the most loathed criminals off death row|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/CRIME/01/12/arizona.judy.clarke.profile/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=26 December 2014}} Pope believes that Clarke was able to humanize Susan Smith and help them see that Smith was herself a victim. Smith was sentenced to life imprisonment with a possibility of parole after 30 years. After the trial, the judge was impressed by Clarke's work and increased her fee to US$83,000. After paying the taxes, she donated the money to a criminal defense fund. ===Theodore Kaczynski=== In 1996, Federal Defender Quin Denvir filed papers asking U.S. District Judge [[Garland Burrell]] to appoint Clarke as his co-counsel for [[Ted Kaczynski]] who was accused of seven explosions connected to the [[Unabomber]] and faced the death penalty.{{cite web|last1=Associated Press|title=Susan Smith's Lawyer to Join Unabomber Defense|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-07-17/news/mn-25012_1_susan-smith-s-life|website=LA Times|accessdate=30 December 2014}} Clarke and the defense made unsuccessful challenges to the search of Kaczynski's cabin and the statements he made after his capture.{{cite book|last1=Bailey|first1=Frankie|title=Crimes and Trials of the Century [2 volumes]|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group}} In addition, the defense began preparation for an insanity defense, which Kaczynski did not support. Kaczynski's brother [[David Kaczynski]] said of Clarke: "She had the ability to develop a relationship with Ted, and that was not one of his gifts. He does not connect easily or well with people." Moreover, he said, "I thought [that] she understands my brother as a human being who has significant issues and challenges and mental problems, who's done something terrible but is still on the level of a human being." About the time of jury selection, Kaczynski moved to dismiss his lawyers, but that motion was denied. The day before the trial was to begin, Kaczynski pleaded guilty to avoid the death penalty, and was sentenced to life in prison without parole, serving his sentence at [[ADX Florence]]. Later Kaczynski was quoted describing Judy Clarke as "a bitch on wheels and a sicko."{{Cite web|url = http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2015/03/judith-clarke-dzokhar-tsarnaev-lawyer|title = Dzhokhar Tsarnaev Has the Most Ferocious Lawyer in America Defending Him|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} ===Buford Furrow=== In 2000, she was appointed to represent Buford O. Furrow, the Aryan Nations member, accused of the [[Los Angeles Jewish Community Center shooting]], and the fatal shooting of a Filipino-American postal worker in 1999. Prosecutors dropped the death penalty when the defense documented and charted Furrow's long history of psychiatric treatment for bipolar disorder. In 2001, Furrow pleaded guilty and was sentenced to five life terms. ===Zacarias Moussaoui=== In 2002, she was appointed co-counsel for 9/11 suspect [[Zacarias Moussaoui]] in [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia]].{{cite web|title=Text of Moussaoui Hearing|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/nation/transcripts/moussaoui061302.htm|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=25 December 2014}} On June 13, 2002, Judge [[Leonie Brinkema]] granted Moussaoui's motion to represent himself and allowed the case to move forward. Clarke then served as standby counsel for Moussaoui.{{cite web|url=http://www.wsuonline.weber.edu/forensics/m2.pdf |format=PDF |title=Stanby Counsel's Reply to the Government's Response toCourt's Order on Computer and Email Evidence |publisher=Wsuonline.weber.edu |accessdate=2015-04-03}} Although Judge Brinkema revoked Moussaoui's self-representation, it appears that Clarke acted as a consultant to the defense.{{cite web|last1=Hammack|first1=Laurence|title=Low-key W&L law professor Judy Clarke takes on Tucson shooting suspect Jared Loughner's case|url=http://ww2.roanoke.com/275512|publisher=Roanoke Times|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141225195117/http://ww2.roanoke.com/275512|archivedate=25 December 2014|df=}} Moussaoui ultimately plead guilty, but was spared the death penalty by a jury. He is serving a life sentence without parole at the Federal [[ADX Supermax]] prison in Florence, Colorado, USA. ===Eric Rudolph=== In 2004, after Defense Attorney Robert Jaffe withdrew from the case, she was appointed lead counsel for [[Eric Rudolph]] who was charged in the [[Centennial Olympic Park bombing]] in 1996 and other bombings a year later.{{cite web|last1=Staff Reports|title=Judy Clarke to defend accused serial bomber|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=20040811&id=e2hWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3PIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3393,67547|website=Google News|publisher=The Spokesman-Review - Aug 11, 2004|accessdate=25 December 2014}} Clarke and the defense tried to suppress evidence, but that motion was denied.{{cite web|title=Bomb Suspect Evidence Admissible at Trial|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/dec/19/nation/na-briefs19.5|website=LA Times|accessdate=26 December 2014}} After the prosecution announced that they would seek the death penalty, a federal judge also rejected a claim by the defense that prosecutors waited too long to announce they would seek the death penalty.{{cite web|author=Charles Montaldo Crime Expert |url=http://crime.about.com/od/current/a/rudolph.htm |title=Eric Rudolph - The Eric Rudolph Case |publisher=Crime.about.com |date= |accessdate=2015-04-03}} In April 2005, Rudolph pleaded guilty avoiding the death penalty.{{cite web|last1=US Courts|title=Rudolph's Plea Agreement|url=http://www.alnd.uscourts.gov/rudolph/PleaAgreement.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070306085630/http://www.alnd.uscourts.gov/rudolph/PleaAgreement.pdf|archivedate=2007-03-06|df=}} He is currently serving life in prison without the possibility of parole at [[ADX Florence]]. ===Jared Lee Loughner=== On January 10, 2011, the [[United States district court]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], [[Arizona]] assigned Clarke as defense counsel to [[Jared Lee Loughner]], the perpetrator of the [[2011 Tucson shooting|January 8, 2011 Tucson, Arizona shooting]]. The Phoenix Public Defenders' Office had requested that Clarke be retained in order to allow Loughner to receive competent counsel without the possibility of a community-wide [[conflict of interest]] arising from proceedings against him for his alleged role in the shooting.{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/2011/01/10/2011-01-10_tucson_wants_famed_unabomber_lawyer_judy_clarke_to_defend_shooting_suspect_jared.html?r=news/ |title=Famed 'Unabomber' lawyer Judy Clarke may defend Tucson shooting suspect|publisher=[[New York Daily News]] |date=2011-01-10 |accessdate=2011-01-10}} On August 7, 2012, Clarke brokered a deal sparing Loughner's life in exchange for a guilty plea to 19 counts, including the wounding of then congresswoman [[Gabrielle Giffords]]. Loughner is serving life in prison without parole at the United States Medical Center for Federal Prisoners in Springfield, MO. ===Dzhokhar Tsarnaev=== On April 29, 2013, Clarke was appointed to the defense team representing [[Boston Marathon bombing]] suspect [[Dzhokhar Tsarnaev]].{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/under-the-radar/2013/04/court-appoints-jared-loughner-defender-for-accused-162890.html |title=Court appoints Jared Loughner's defense attorney for accused Boston bomber |publisher=Politico |date=2013-04-29}} Clarke admitted her client's guilt and told the jury that he was responsible for the "senseless, horrific, misguided acts" referring to Tsarnaev's bombing of the Boston marathon.{{Cite web|url = http://abcnews.go.com/US/boston-marathon-bombing-inside-dzhokhar-tsarnaevs-defense-strategy/story?id=29405323|title = Boston Marathon Bombing: Inside Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's 'It Was Him' Defense Strategy|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} A federal jury convicted Tsarnaev of all 30 charges against him and found him responsible for the deaths of the three people killed in the 2013 attack and the killing of an MIT police officer three days later.{{cite web|last1=Lavoie|first1=Denise|title=Tsarnaev's lawyer faces perhaps her biggest challenge yet|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/tsarnaevs-lawyer-faces-perhaps-her-biggest-challenge-yet/|website=seattletimes.com|publisher=Seattle Times|accessdate=9 April 2015}} On May 15, 2015, a federal jury sentenced him to death.{{cite web|last1=Seelye|first1=Katharine|title=Dzhokhar Tsarnaev Gets Death Penalty in Boston Marathon Bombing|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/16/us/dzhokhar-tsarnaev-death-sentence.html|website=nytimes.com|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=15 May 2015}} ===Representation style and views=== In a speech at [[Loyola Law School]], Clarke in essence said that her clients—no matter how horrible the crimes they are accused of committing—are real people, not monsters, and that she tries to understand what caused them to do it. She opposes capital punishment.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/11/us/11defender.html |title=Loughner's Lawyer Is Called a Master Strategist |publisher=The New York Times |author=William Glaberson |date=2011-01-10 |accessdate=2011-01-11 }} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://law.wlu.edu/faculty/profiledetail.asp?id=209 Judy Clarke] at [[Washington and Lee University School of Law]] *[http://www.fdsdi.com/our_history.html History] at Federal Defenders of San Diego Inc. * [http://www.politicsdaily.com/2011/01/11/judy-clarke-jared-loughners-amazing-attorney/?ncid=webmail Judy Clarke: Jared Loughner's 'Amazing' Attorney] {{DEFAULTSORT:Clarke, Judy}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Furman University alumni]] [[Category:University of South Carolina alumni]] [[Category:Washington and Lee University School of Law faculty]] [[Category:California lawyers]] [[Category:American women lawyers]] [[Category:Public defenders]] [[Category:American anti–death penalty activists]] [[Category:Legal scholars]] [[Category:People from Asheville, North Carolina]] [[Category:Criminal defense lawyers]]

{{About|the sexual assaults in Taiwan|the American actor|Justin Lee (actor)|other uses|Justin Lee (disambiguation)}} The '''Justin Lee sex scandal''' involves a Taiwanese man, Justin Lee ({{zh|c=李宗瑞|=Li Zongrui}}; born 1985), who was convicted of nine rapes, during which he had drugged women and then recorded the sexual assaults.
Lee is the son of former Yuanta Financial Holding Co board member Lee Yueh-tsang, and known for his presence at attending fashion parties and nightclubs. In 2011 two sisters filed police report against Lee. During the investigation, the police discovered recorded files on Lee's computer and arrested him in November 2012. Prosecutors said that since August 2009, Lee had been drugging women or getting them drunk in luxury nightclubs around Taiwan, before taking them to his home to rape them while unconscious. Lee fled Taipei and was on the run for 23 days before turning himself in.<ref>http://news.asiaone.com/news/crime/jail-term-justin-lee-over-unauthorised-filming-can-be-commuted-fine-instead?nopaging=1</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/national/national-news/2013/09/04/388061/Justin-Lee.htm |title=Justin Lee gets 18 years' prison for sex assault |newspaper=[[The China Post]] |date= |accessdate=2016-10-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/entertainment/22-years-jail-for-sexual/800446.html |title=22 years' jail for sexual assault involving Taiwanese {{Other uses|Kiwi (disambiguation)}} [[File:Kiwi holding kiwi.jpg|upright|thumb|A Kiwi holding a [[kiwi]]]] '''Kiwi''' ({{IPAc-en|k|iː|w|iː}}) is the nickname used internationally for [[New Zealanders|people from New Zealand]],<ref>{{cite web|title=the definition of kiwis|url=http://www.dictionary.com/browse/kiwis|publisher=Dictionary.com|accessdate=4 June 2017}}</ref><ref name="DOC1"/> as well as being a relatively common self-reference.<ref name="glossary"/> Unlike many demographic labels, its usage is not considered offensive; rather, it is generally viewed as a symbol of pride and [[Term of endearment|endearment]] for the people of New Zealand.<ref name="origins"/> The name derives from the [[kiwi]], a native [[flightless bird]], which is a [[National symbols of New Zealand|national symbol]] of New Zealand. Until the [[First World War]], the kiwi represented the country and not the people; however, by 1917, New Zealanders were also being called "Kiwis", supplanting other nicknames.
==History== ===Representing the nation=== The kiwi has long had a special significance for the [[indigenous peoples|indigenous]] [[Māori people]], who used its skin to make [[Māori traditional textiles|feather cloaks]] (''kahu kiwi'') for chiefs.<ref name="Phillips">{{cite web|first=Jock|last= Phillips|title=Kiwi - Kiwi and people: early history|publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|date=July 2012|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/kiwi/page-4|access-date=4 June 2017}}</ref> The bird first came to European attention in 1811 when a skin ended up in the hands of a British Museum zoologist, [[George Shaw]], who classified it as a type of [[penguin]] and portrayed it as standing upright.<ref>{{cite web|title=Early impacts|url=https://www.kiwisforkiwi.org/about-kiwi/threats/people/early-impacts/|publisher=The Kiwi Trust|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Phillips|first1=Jock|title=Early European engraving|url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/artwork/10186/early-european-engraving|publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> After early sightings by Europeans the kiwi was regarded as a curiosity; in 1835 the missionary [[William Yate]] described it as "the most remarkable and curious bird in New Zealand".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Yate|first1=William|title=An account of New Zealand and of the formation and progress of the Church Missionary Society’s mission in the northern island|date=1835|publisher=Seeley and Burnside|location=London|page=5}}</ref>
In the early 1900s cartoonists began to use the kiwi as a representation of New Zealand. For example, in a 1904 ''New Zealand Free Lance'' cartoon a plucky kiwi is shown growing to a [[moa]] after a rugby victory of 9–3 over a British team.<ref name="kiwi cartoons">{{cite web|title=First use of kiwi as unofficial national symbol?|url=https://nzhistory.govt.nz/page/first-use-kiwi-unofficial-national-symbol|publisher=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|accessdate=17 August 2017|date=27 July 2017}}</ref> The next year, ''[[The Westminster Gazette]]'' printed a cartoon of a kiwi and a [[kangaroo]] (representing Australia) going off to a colonial conference.<ref name="kiwi cartoons"/> [[Trevor Lloyd (artist)|Trevor Lloyd]], who worked for ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]'', also used a kiwi to represent the [[All Blacks]] rugby team, but he more often drew a moa.<ref name="Phillips"/> Other symbols for New Zealand at this time included the [[silver fern]], a small boy and a young lion cub.<ref name="kiwi cartoons"/> But until the [[First World War]] the kiwi was used as a symbol of the nation rather than the people of New Zealand.<ref name="Phillips"/>
===Representing the people=== [[File:Roundel of New Zealand.svg|thumb|200px|[[Royal New Zealand Air Force]] (RNZAF) roundel, featuring a red kiwi in silhouette]] In the early-20th century New Zealanders—including soldiers and All Blacks players—were referred to internationally as "En Zed(der)s",<ref name="Phillips"/> or "Maorilanders" (referring to the Māori people and their historical contribution to the country).<ref>{{cite web|first= Jock|last= Phillips|title= The New Zealanders - Maorilanders|publisher= Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|date= March 2009|url= http://www.TeAra.govt.nz/en/the-new-zealanders/5 |accessdate= 27 February 2011}}</ref> These terms were still being used near the end of the First World War of 1914-1918. However, although New Zealand soldiers were often described as [[Digger (soldier) | "Diggers"]] or as "Pig Islanders",<ref> The ''Oxford Dictionary of New Zealand English'' (1997) records the use of "pig-islander" from 1909. </ref> by 1917 they were also being called "Kiwis".<ref name="Phillips" /><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.teara.govt.nz/TheBush/NativeBirdsAndBats/Kiwi/5/en |title= Kiwi - A kiwi country: 1930s–2000s |publisher= Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |date= 2011-05-24 |accessdate= 2012-09-13}}</ref>
The image of the kiwi had appeared on military badges since the South Canterbury Battalion used it in 1886,<ref>{{cite web|last1= Phillips|first1= Jock|title= South Canterbury Battalion badge|url =http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/object/10189/south-canterbury-battalion-badge|website= www.teara.govt.nz|publisher= Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate= 4 June 2017|language= en|date= 24 September 2007}}</ref> and several [[regiment]]s took it up in the First World War. "Kiwis" came to mean the men of New Zealand regiments.<ref name="Phillips" /> The nickname is not thought to have originated as a reference to the physical attributes of the New Zealand servicemen (i.e. implying they were short and stocky or nocturnal like the bird). It was simply that the kiwi was distinct and unique to the country.<ref name="Phillips" /> Its prominent use on the New Zealand regiments' insignia also made for easy association.<ref name="origins">{{cite web|last1= Norah|first1= Laurence|title= Kiwis, Poms and other naming mysteries|url= http://www.findingtheuniverse.com/2010/12/kiwis-poms-and-other-naming-mysteries.html|publisher= Finding the Universe|accessdate= 4 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1= Jock|first1= Phillips|title= RNZAF Harvard|url= http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/10191/rnzaf-harvard|publisher= Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|date= 24 September 2007|accessdate= 4 June 2017}}</ref> The nickname eventually became common usage in all war [[Theater (warfare)|theatres]].<ref name="Phillips"/> [[File:Bulford, England. Chalk Kiwi from Postcard, c.1919.jpg|thumb|left|200px| Chalk kiwi above the town of [[Bulford]], executed in 1919]] After the end of the First World War in November 1918, many New Zealand troops stayed in Europe for months or years awaiting transport home. At [[Sling Camp]], near Bulford on [[Salisbury Plain]] in [[Wiltshire]], New Zealand soldiers carved a [[Bulford Kiwi| chalk kiwi]] into the nearby hill in early 1919.<ref> [https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1443438 Kiwi Chalk Figure above Bulford Camp] "Members of the Canterbury, Otago and Wellington Battalions under Captain Harry Clark created a chalk figure of a kiwi bird in the nearby hillside in April-June 1919 by removing 12in of top soil and replacing it with chalk pebbles. The kiwi was designed by Sergeant Major Percy Blenkarne, a drawing instructor in the New Zealand Army Education Corps." </ref><ref>Compare: {{cite web|url= http://www.wiltshire-web.co.uk/history/horse.htm |title= The White Horses |publisher= Wiltshire-web.co.uk |date= |accessdate= 2012-09-13}}</ref> The New Zealanders' presence popularised the nickname within Europe.<ref name="Phillips" />
[[File:Kiwi polish black.jpg|thumb|200px|A can of [[Kiwi (shoe polish) |Kiwi shoe polish]]]] An Australian [[boot polish]] called ''[[Kiwi (shoe polish) |Kiwi]]'' was widely used in the imperial forces. [[William Ramsay]], a developer of the product, named the polish in honour of his wife's birthplace, New Zealand.<ref name="Phillips"/> Beginning in 1906, Kiwi Shoe Polish eventually became widely sold in the UK and the US, and the symbol became more widely known.<ref>{{cite book|last1= Brooks|first1= Miki|title= Lessons From a Land Down Under: Devotions from New Zealand|publisher= Lulu|isbn= 9780557098842|pages= 3–4|url= https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=JI-NBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA3&lpg=PA3|language= en}}</ref> ''[[The Australian National Dictionary]]''<ref>{{cite web |editor-first= Bill|editor-last= Ramson|title= Australian National Dictionary|publisher= Oxford University Press Australia & New Zealand|year= 2008|url= http://australiannationaldictionary.com.au}}</ref> also gives the first use of the term "Kiwi Kids" and "Kiwis" in 1917, to mean Australian army recruits who had ''kiwied up''; in other words, they had highly-polished boots.<ref>{{cite book|first1= Christine |last1= Franzen|first2= Laurie|last2= Bauer|title= Of Pavlova, Poetry, and Paradigms|publisher= Victoria University Press|year= 1993|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=hm-hXVgYBaEC&pg=PA16 }}</ref>
Following the [[Second World War]] of 1939-1945 the term gradually became attributed to all New Zealanders, and today throughout the world they are referred to as Kiwis, as well as often referring to themselves that way.<ref name="DOC1">{{cite web|title= Kiwi|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/nature/native-animals/birds/birds-a-z/kiwi/|website= www.doc.govt.nz|publisher= New Zealand Department of Conservation|accessdate= 4 June 2017|language= en}}</ref><ref name="glossary"> {{cite web |url= http://glossary.immigration.govt.nz/Kiwis.htm |title= Kiwis/Kiwi - New Zealand Immigration Service (Summary of Terms) |website= Glossary.immigration.govt.nz |date= |accessdate= 2012-09-13 }} </ref>
==Current usage== Spelling of the word ''Kiwi'', when used to describe the people, is often capitalised, and takes the [[plural]] form ''Kiwis''. The bird's name is spelled with a lower-case ''k'' and, being a word of [[Māori language|Māori]] origin, normally stays as ''kiwi'' when pluralised.<ref>{{cite web|title=Plurals in te reo Māori|url=http://www.stats.govt.nz/about_us/what-we-do/our-publications/style-guides/style-manual/maori-language.aspx|publisher=Statistics New Zealand|accessdate=17 August 2017|language=en-nz|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818045202/http://www.stats.govt.nz/about_us/what-we-do/our-publications/style-guides/style-manual/maori-language.aspx|archivedate=18 August 2017|df=}}</ref> Thus, "two Kiwis" refers to two people, whereas "two kiwi" refers to two birds. This linguistic nicety is well exemplified by the [[Bank of New Zealand|BNZ]] Save the Kiwi Conservation Trust, which uses the slogan "Kiwis for kiwi".<ref>{{cite web|title=Kiwis for kiwi|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/kiwis-for-kiwi|website=www.doc.govt.nz|publisher=New Zealand Department of Conservation|accessdate=4 June 2017|language=en}}</ref>
It is not usually considered to be a [[derogatory term]].<ref name="origins"/> In an official context, "Kiwi" has been used in the name of government services and state-owned enterprises, such as [[KiwiBuild]], [[KiwiSaver]], [[KiwiRail]] and [[Kiwibank]].
==See also== {{Portal|New Zealand}} * [[Bloke]] * [[Kiwiana]], items or icons particular to New Zealand * [[Kiwifruit]], fruit associated with New Zealand, but ''not native to it'', which is also known as the "Chinese Gooseberry" * [[Māori people|Māori]], the indigenous Polynesian people of New Zealand * [[Pākehā]], non-Māori (especially European) New Zealanders * [[.kiwi]], an internet domain name * [[British people|Brit]] * [[Yankee]] * [[Canuck]] * [[Aussie]]

Historically, many ethnic Macanese spoke [[Macanese language|Patuá]], which is a [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]-based [[creole language|creole]] and now virtually extinct. Many are fluent in both [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and [[Cantonese]]. The Macanese have preserved a distinctive [[Macanese cuisine]]. == History == ===The Portuguese Period=== [[File:The Macanese, Miguel António de Cortela.jpg|thumb|''The Macanese, Miguel António de Cortela''. Attributed to [[Lam Qua]], early to mid-19th century.]] Macau was founded circa 1557 by Portuguese merchants with permission of the Chinese Canton governor and later the emperor. Since its beginning, Macau has not been conquered and until the attacks of the Dutch in 1604, it didn´t have a military garrison. Portuguese culture dominates the Macanese, but Chinese cultural patterns are also significant. The community acted as the interface between Portuguese merchant settlers or ruling [[Colonialism|colonial]] government - Portuguese from Portugal who knew little about Chinese - and the Chinese majority (90% of population) who knew equally little about the Portuguese. Some Macanese had paternal Portuguese heritage.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} Some were Portuguese men stationed in Macau as part of their military service. Many stayed in Macau after the expiration of their military service, marrying Macanese women. Rarely did Chinese women marry Portuguese; initially, mostly [[Goans]], [[Sinhalese people|Ceylonese/Sinhalese]] (from today's Sri Lanka), Indochina, Malay (from [[Malacca]]), and Japanese women were the wives of the Portuguese men in Macau.{{cite book|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|year=2003|location=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kwZwFh1aqFUC&pg=PR10#v=onepage&q&f=false|quote= |volume=|page=x|title=Taste of Macau: Portuguese Cuisine on the China Coast|isbn=962-209-638-7|author=Annabel Jackson|edition=illustrated|accessdate=2014-02-02}}{{cite book |author=João de Pina-Cabral|title=Between China and Europe: person, culture and emotion in Macao|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GglrUksvCUcC&pg=PA39&dq=portuguese+slave+tanka&hl=en&sa=X&ei=r-NOT8r_JoaQ0QGBhYzdDQ&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=portuguese%20slave%20tanka&f=false|accessdate=2012-03-01 |type= |edition=illustrated|series= |volume=Volume 74 of London School of Economics monographs on social anthropology|date= |year=2002|month= |origyear= |publisher=Berg|location= |language= |isbn=0-8264-5749-5|page=39 |at= |chapter= |quote=To be a Macanese is fundamentally to be from Macao with Portuguese ancestors, but not necessarily to be of Sino-Portuguese descent.
