[[File:To young men only.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Cover of the 1980 pamphlet, which printed the sermon.]]'''"To Young Men Only"''' (also known as '''"Message to Young Men"'''<ref>{{cite web|title=General Conference: October 1976|url=https://www.lds.org/general-conference/1976/10/?lang=eng|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>) is a sermon delivered by [[Mormon]] [[apostle (Latter Day Saints)|apostle]] [[Boyd K. Packer]] on October 2, 1976, at the [[Priesthood (LDS Church)|priesthood]] session of the 146th Semiannual [[General Conference (LDS Church)|General Conference]] of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church). The sermon is addressed to young men of the [[Aaronic priesthood (Latter Day Saints)|Aaronic priesthood]] (ages 12 to 18) and discusses issues of [[human sexuality]], [[puberty]], and morality. From 1980 to 2016, the sermon was published as a pamphlet by the LDS Church. It has been criticized on various grounds, such as that it encourages [[Violence against LGBT people|violence against homosexuals]]. In 2016, the church discontinued the pamphlet.<ref name = 2016retired>[[Peggy Fletcher Stack]], [http://www.sltrib.com/home/4584556-155/lds-church-retires-mormon-apostles-little "LDS Church 'retires' Mormon apostle's 'little factory' pamphlet"], ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'', November 14, 2016.</ref>
==Content== Packer described his remarks as matters that "fathers should discuss with their sons."<ref name = TYMO/> Packer stated that "because some young men do not have fathers and because some fathers (and some bishops) do not know how to proceed", he would be addressing sensitive subjects.<ref name=TYMO>{{cite web |last1=Packer |first1=Boyd |title=To Young Men Only |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151021234056/https://www.lds.org/manual/to-young-men-only/to-young-men-only |url=https://www.lds.org/manual/to-young-men-only/to-young-men-only |dead-url=yes |website=lds.org |publisher=LDS Church |archive-date=21 October 2015}}</ref> The sermon compares the [[male reproductive system]] to a "little factory" and teaches that [[masturbation]], use of [[pornography]], and [[homosexuality|homosexual activities]] are immoral and forbidden by God.<ref name = TYMO/> It encourages young male Latter-day Saints to "vigorously resist" homosexual advances, even with violence, if necessary.<ref name=Quote /> Packer teaches that [[nocturnal emission]] is natural and designed by God and that young men "should not feel guilty" when it happens.<ref name = TYMO/> The sermon also offers suggestions on how to control one's thoughts and resist temptation.<ref name = TYMO/>
==Publication== Unlike most general conference sermons, "Message to Young Men" was not published in the church's official magazine, ''[[Ensign (LDS magazine)|The Ensign]].''<ref>{{Citation|last=|first=|title=Report of the 146th Semiannual Conference of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|date=November 1976|url=https://www.lds.org/ensign/1976/11?lang=eng|magazine=[[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]]|volume=6|issue=11|type=Magazine|access-date=2018-10-24}}. Note that the table of contents for this issue lacks any reference to this address.</ref> Instead, the sermon was published in 1980 as a 14-page pamphlet, entitled "To Young Men Only", that was available for church leaders to distribute to members.<ref name="TYMO" />
In 2016, the pamphlet was discontinued and it was removed from the LDS Church's website.<ref name="2016retired" /> The video of the sermon remains available on the LDS Church's website.<ref name="2016retired" /><ref name="TYMO" />
==Criticism==
[[File:ToYoungMenOnly.png|thumb|right|150px|Packer's conference address published here has been criticized of condoning anti-gay violence.<ref name="Multiply">{{cite book|last1=Corcoran|first1=Brent|last2=O'Donovan|first2=Rocky|title=Multiply and Replenish: Mormon Essays on Sex and Family|date=1994|publisher=Signature Books|location=Salt Lake City, Utah|isbn=1560850507|url=http://signaturebookslibrary.org/the-abominable-and-detestable-crime-against-nature/|accessdate=29 November 2016}}</ref>{{rp|150}}<ref name="Criticism" >Hilary Groutage Smith, "Mormon Pamphlets on Gays Criticized", ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'', 2000-08-06, p. B2</ref><ref name="Dynamics" /><ref name="BYU Dismissal">David E. Hardy, "BYU's Dismissal of Gay Students Continues Confusion for Gays, Parents" [opinion], ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'', p. AA3.</ref>]] One controversial part of the sermon states that some men entice others to join them in sexual behaviors and gives an example of a missionary who punched his companion to the floor for making sexual advances to which Packer responded, "Somebody had to do it".<ref name=Quote>{{cite web |last1=Packer |first1=Boyd |title=To Young Men Only |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151021234056/https://www.lds.org/manual/to-young-men-only/to-young-men-only |url=https://www.lds.org/manual/to-young-men-only/to-young-men-only |dead-url=yes |website=lds.org |publisher=LDS Church |archive-date=21 October 2015 |quote=There are some men who entice young men to join them in these immoral acts. If you are ever approached to participate in anything like that, it is time to vigorously resist. While I was in a mission on one occasion, a missionary said he had something to confess. I was very worried because he just could not get himself to tell me what he had done. After patient encouragement he finally blurted out, 'I hit my companion.' 'Oh, is that all,' I said in great relief. 'But I floored him,' he said. After learning a little more, my response was 'Well, thanks. Somebody had to do it, and it wouldn't be well for a General Authority to solve the problem that way.' I am not recommending that course to you, but I am not omitting it. You must protect yourself.}}</ref> The audience is heard laughing after this statement in the original broadcast.<ref>{{cite AV media |people=Packer, Boyd |date=October 1976 |title=Message to Young Men |time=11:21 |url=https://www.lds.org/general-conference/1976/10/media/session_5_talk_1/2680671857001?lang=eng |location=Salt Lake Tabernacle |publisher=LDS Church}}</ref>
In 2001, gay Mormon historian [[D. Michael Quinn]] described the sermon as "[t]he low point in the Mormon hierarchy's homophobia since the 1950s";<ref name="Dynamics">[[D. Michael Quinn]], ''Same-sex Dynamics Among Nineteenth-century Americans: A Mormon Example'' (Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 2001) p. 382.</ref> Quinn argued that Packer's words constituted an endorsement of [[gay bashing]] and that the church itself endorsed such behavior by continuing to publish Packer's speech.<ref name=dialogue>[[D. Michael Quinn]], [https://www.dialoguejournal.com/wp-content/uploads/sbi/articles/Dialogue_V33N03_13.pdf "Prelude to the National 'Defense of Marriage' Campaign: Civil Discrimination Against Feared or Despised Minorities"], ''[[Dialogue: A Journal of Mormon Thought]]'' vol. 33 no. 3 (Fall 2000) pp. 1–52.</ref>
In 2000 and 2001, David E. Hardy, a [[Salt Lake City]] lawyer who is the father of a gay son, criticized the sermon for "demoniz[ing]" gays and implying that "[[homosexuality]] is a matter of choice".<ref>Hilary Groutage Smith, "Mormon Pamphlets on Gays Criticized", ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'', 2000-08-06, p. B2</ref><ref>David E. Hardy, "BYU's Dismissal of Gay Students Continues Confusion for Gays, Parents" [opinion], ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'', p. AA3.</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Packer |first1=Boyd |title=To Young Men Only |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151021234056/https://www.lds.org/manual/to-young-men-only/to-young-men-only |url=https://www.lds.org/manual/to-young-men-only/to-young-men-only |dead-url=yes |website=lds.org |publisher=LDS Church |archive-date=21 October 2015 |quote=There is a falsehood that some are born with an attraction to their own kind, with nothing they can do about it. They are just 'that way' and can only yield to those desires. That is a malicious and destructive lie. While it is a convincing idea to some, it is of the devil. No one is locked into that kind of life. From our premortal life we were directed into a physical body. There is no mismatching of bodies and spirits. Boys are to become men—masculine, manly men—ultimately to become husbands and fathers. No one is predestined to a perverted use of these powers.}}</ref>
In 2014, Samantha Allen, a columnist for ''[[The Daily Beast]]'', wrote that the sermon "typifies organized religion’s approach to curtailing male masturbation", calling it "deeply paternalistic" and criticizing it for employing "a noxious mixture of condescension and euphemism".<ref>Samantha Allen, [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/08/01/tim-ferriss-is-bro-culture-s-anti-masturbation-crusader.html "Tim Ferriss Is Bro Culture's Anti-Masturbation Crusader"], ''[[The Daily Beast]]'', August 1, 2014.</ref>
